Title: Ten years of research on group size and helping
Affiliations: Ohio State U, Behavioral Sciences Lab, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Latané, B., Ohio State U, Behavioral Sciences Lab, Columbus, United States; Nida, S.
Abstract: Reviews research that attempts to replicate and extend B. Latané and J. M. Dabbs's (1970) discovery that the presence of other people inhibits an individual from intervening in an emergency. Particular attention is paid to the nature of the precipitating incident, the ambiguity of the helping situation, laboratory vs field settings, characteristics of the Ss, victims, and other bystanders, and the amount and kinds of communication among bystanders. It is concluded that, despite the diversity of styles, settings, and techniques among the studies, the social inhibition of helping is a remarkably consistent phenomenon; however, victims are more likely to receive assistance when only a single individual witnesses the emergency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: presence of others & social influence & diffusion of responsibility, helping behavior in emergencies, review of research
Correspondence Address: Latané, B.; Ohio State U, , Columbus, United States

Title: Juror decision-making models: The generalization gap
Authors with affiliations: Pennington, N., Northwestern U; Hastie, R.
Abstract: Evaluates psychological and mathematical models that have been applied to individual juror decision making and identifies 3 research goals: to gain insight into adult cognition in a complex, naturally occurring reasoning task, to extend existing psychological models of decision making and judgment, and to provide empirical data on questions of interest to the legal community. A task analysis is presented in the form of an ideal juror model to describe and evaluate empirical research with respect to these goals. Component processes proposed in each model and empirical findings are compared across models and in relation to the task analysis. Models examined include information integration, Bayesian, Poisson, sequential weighting, and nonmodels. It is concluded that laboratory model applications to actual complex reasoning tasks must be based on thorough task analyses to avoid conflict between research goals and to facilitate generalization to natural settings. (130 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: psychological & mathematical models & research goals, individual juror decision making, literature review
Correspondence Address: Pennington, N.

Title: Reevaluation of the literature on the development of transitive inferences
Authors with affiliations: Breslow, L., U California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Reevaluates literature on the development of transitive inferences, particularly criticisms raised by T. Trabasso et al (1975, 1977) regarding Piaget's theory of transitive inference ability. Trabasso claims to have demonstrated that the conceptual understanding underlying transitive reasoning does not develop with age, as Piaget claimed, but can be found among Ss as young as 4 yrs of age if language comprehension and memory are controlled. In reply, the difficulty of distinguishing between the understanding of lower and higher level Ss on the basis of average performance over many trials is discussed. Instead of analyzing data from the early and later trials of the task, it is suggested that Ss' behavior be analyzed as it evolves during the tasks to assess the concepts with which Ss approach them. Neither the creation nor the use of a seriated ordering by Ss in Trabasso's tasks is considered to provide evidence against the structural developmental account of transitivity. It is concluded that there is no evidence that conceptual structures can be reduced to information-processing systems derived from conceptual structures. (69 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theories & experimental methodology, development of transitive inferences, reevaluation of literature
Correspondence Address: Breslow, L.; U California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Time and method in coaching for the SAT
Affiliations: Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Messick, S., Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States; Jungeblut, A.
Abstract: A review of studies of coaching for the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) indicates that, although there are methodological flaws, some definite regularities emerge relating the size of score effects associated with coaching to the amount of student contact time entailed in the coaching programs. Rank-order correlations between these 2 variables were upwards of .7 for both SAT-Verbal (SAT-V) and SAT-Mathematics (SAT-M) scales. The relationship was nonlinear with arithmetically increasing amounts of score effect associated with geometrically increasing amounts of student contact time. Thus, diminishing returns in SAT coaching effects, especially for SAT-V, were found. According to the logarithmic models' fit to the data, the student contact time required to achieve average score increases of more than 20-30 points (on a 200-800 point scale) for both SAT-V and SAT-M rapidly approaches that of full-time schooling. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: coaching method & time, Scholastic Aptitude Test verbal & mathematics scale scores, literature review
Correspondence Address: Messick, S.; Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States

Authors: McCusker L.X., Hillinger M.L., Bias R.G.
Title: Phonological recoding and reading
Affiliations: Bell Labs, Piscataway, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: McCusker, L.X., Bell Labs, Piscataway, NJ, United States; Hillinger, M.L.; Bias, R.G.
Abstract: Examines contradictory research that attempted to determine whether the process of lexical access in silent reading is mediated by an internal phonological representation or only by visual representations. More recent evidence is discussed that suggests that factors such as difficulty of material, frequency of occurrence of items, Ss' fluency, and task demands--which are seldom manipulated in typical studies of word recognition--play important roles in determining the type of mediation used. It is noted that interest has shifted to a family of dual access models in which both phonological mediation and visual mediation are ordinarily used in parallel. Thus, data point to a dual access model in which high-frequency words enjoy high-speed access via a visually based representation, whereas low-frequency words are accessed using a slower, phonological recoding process. (113 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: phonological recoding vs visual mediation, lexical access in silent reading, literature review
Correspondence Address: McCusker, L.X.; Bell Labs, Piscataway, NJ, United States

Title: Mutual influence in expressive behavior: Adult-adult and infant-adult dyadic interaction
Authors with affiliations: Cappella, J.N., U Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Reviews literature on the influence of speaker's expressive behaviors on another's behavioral response in adult-adult and infant-adult dyads. Expressive behaviors include noncontent speech variables; indicators of affiliation such as gaze, distance, orientation, and question intimacy; verbal disclosure; body movements; and general indices of involvement. Interspeaker influence includes both interspeaker matching and compensation in overt behavior. Matching predominates in noncontent speech, verbal disclosure, and gaze. Compensatory responses are prompted by question intimacy and proximity. Both reciprocal and compensatory responses show limits, and are attenuated and even reversed by moderator variables associated with person differences and social-normative expectations. Continuities between adult-adult and infant-adult dyads are found for vocalization and gaze. Explanations of expressive social interaction must be flexible enough to account for both compensation and matching as well as the limits to and moderators of these responses. (51/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: speakers' expressive behaviors, behavioral responses, adult-adult & infant-adult dyads, literature review

Title: Lateral brain function, emotion, and conceptualization
Affiliations: U North Dakota, Grand Forks, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tucker, D.M., U North Dakota, Grand Forks, United States
Abstract: Reviews research on brain damage, psychiatric disorders, and normal emotion, which has shown the importance of the right hemisphere's holistic and nonverbal conceptualization to emotion. Studies of hemispheric asymmetries in psychiatric patients have suggested the importance of specific and apparently lateralized arousal systems in the brain that support the differential cognitive capacities of the 2 cerebral hemispheres. The operation of these arousal systems seems to vary closely with the individual's affective state. Research on emotional effects of unilateral lesions has suggested that the hemispheres may be specialized not just for the kind of emotion but for its valence, positive or negative. Research issues and methods in this area are still at an early stage of development, yet it seems clear that further research on the lateralization of emotion should reveal how emotional processes are at one level dependent on basic neurophysiological activation processes and at another level intrinsic to the differential forms of conceptualization of the 2 cerebral hemispheres. (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: importance of right hemisphere's holistic & nonverbal conceptualization to emotion & role of neurophysiological activation processes, review of literature on brain damage to psychiatric disorders & emotions

Title: Asymmetry of cerebral hemispheric function in normal and poor readers
Authors with affiliations: Young, A.W., U Lancaster, England, United Kingdom; Ellis, A.W.
Abstract: Reviews studies that have attempted to use methods of brief lateral visual presentation of linguistic stimuli to investigate asymmetry of organization of cerebral hemispheric functions in normal and poor readers. It is argued that any between-group differences found in such studies can be properly interpreted only when it is known that Ss in both groups approached the given tasks in the same way. It is shown that most existing studies have failed to meet this requirement because of failure to control Ss' central fixation, failure to demonstrate that the same types of stimuli were recognized by normal and poor readers, failure to take into account the possibility that normal and poor readers may have used different strategies or processes to accomplish particular tasks, and failure to compare groups of normal and poor readers matched on reading ability. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: brief lateral visual presentation of linguistic stimuli, asymmetry of cerebral hemispheric function, normal & poor readers, literature review

Title: Visual search and number of stimuli reexamined
Affiliations: U London, Birkbeck Coll, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Barber, P., U London, Birkbeck Coll, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Criticizes W. H. Teichner and M. J. Krebs's (see record 1974-10297-001) analysis of search performance across experiments. Methodological weaknesses in their review include (among others) insufficient data to warrant the inclusion of alpha-numeric search tasks. Theoretically, the concept of stimulus grouping is vague and not clearly distinguished in practice from parallel processing. Evidence is noted that is inconsistent with some inferred characteristics of their data base. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: number of stimuli in visual search performance, methodological criticisms of W. H. Teichner & M. J. Krebs

Authors: Spetch M.L., Wilkie D.M., Pinel J.P.
Title: Backward conditioning: A reevaluation of the empirical evidence
Authors with affiliations: Spetch, M.L., U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Wilkie, D.M.; Pinel, J.P.
Abstract: Comments that there is an apparent discrepancy between the widespread view that backward conditioning does not occur and the experimental evidence that suggests that it does. Backward pairing of CSs and UCSs frequently has resulted in effects similar to those produced by forward pairing, and results of several recent experiments have established that such effects cannot be attributed to factors other than stimulus pairing per se. Surprisingly, even some of the earlier experiments that provided the basis for the current skepticism concerning backward conditioning provide evidence of its existence. The failure to recognize backward conditioning as a legitimate phenomenon seems to reflect theoretical biases rather than a paucity of empirical evidence. Thus, backward conditioning and its properties merit renewed interest and reexamination. (47 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: backward conditioning, literature review & reevaluation of empirical evidence
Index Keywords: animal; article; avoidance behavior; conditioned reflex; rat; Animal; Avoidance Learning; Conditioning, Classical; Rats; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: Feature detectors for speech: A critical reappraisal
Authors with affiliations: Diehl, R.L., U Texas, Austin, United States
Abstract: A review of the literature shows that in the past decade, most theoretical accounts of speech perception have stressed the role of feature detectors in mapping initial auditory transforms of the speech signal onto features or phonemes. Several types of experiments are often viewed as supporting the feature detector hypothesis. These include electrophysiological studies of the visual and auditory systems of nonhuman species, studies of categorical perception of speech sounds by human adults and infants, and especially, studies of selective adaptation to speech sounds. The present article argues that evidence for feature detectors in speech perception is equivocal at best and that there are compelling reasons to reject the detector hypothesis (e.g., lack of firm consensus regarding the nature of detector outputs). (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: feature detectors, mapping initial auditory transforms of speech signal onto features or phonemes, literature review

Title: Effects of cooperative, competitive, and individualistic goal structures on achievement: A meta-analysis
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, D.W., U Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; et al
Abstract: Reviewed 122 studies (listed in an appendix) and compared the relative effectiveness of cooperation, cooperation with intergroup competition, interpersonal competition, and individualistic goal structures in promoting achievement and productivity in North American samples. These studies yielded 286 findings. Three meta-analysis procedures were used: voting method, effect-size method, and z-score method. Results indicate that (a) cooperation is considerably more effective than interpersonal competition and individualistic efforts, (b) cooperation with intergroup competition is also superior to interpersonal competition and individualistic efforts, and (c) there is no significant difference between interpersonal competitive and individualistic efforts. Through multiple regression, a number of potentially mediating variables for these results are identified. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: meta-analysis of cooperation & cooperation with intergroup competition & interpersonal competition & individualistic goal structures, promotion of achievement & productivity, review of North American samples
Correspondence Address: Johnson, D.W.; U Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States

Title: Memory span: Sources of individual and developmental differences
Affiliations: U Nevada Coll of Education, Las Vegas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dempster, F.N., U Nevada Coll of Education, Las Vegas, United States
Abstract: Examines 10 possible sources of individual and developmental differences in memory span (rehearsal, grouping, chunking, retrieval strategies, item identification, item ordering, capacity, susceptibility to interference, search rate, and the output buffer) by drawing on existing research. Considerable evidence suggests that the speed with which presented items can be identified is a major source of both individual and developmental differences in span. By contrast, there is no conclusive evidence that the other possibilities examined, including those traditionally associated with span differences (rehearsal, grouping, chunking, and overall information-processing capacity), contribute to variations in span. Speed of item identification differences is discussed in terms of processing efficiency or the capacity needed to activate appropriate perceptual/cognitive units and linguistic programs. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sources of individual & developmental differences in memory span, literature review
Correspondence Address: Dempster, F.N.; U Nevada Coll of Education, Las Vegas, United States

Title: Foreperiod and simple reaction time
Authors with affiliations: Niemi, P., U Turku, Finland; Näätänen, R.
Abstract: Reviews studies of simple visual and auditory reaction processes published since W. H. Teicher (1954), with emphasis on the preparatory phase of these processes, particularly the foreperiod (FP). The 1st section consists of the analysis of actual FP variables; duration, regularity, range, distribution, and preceding FPs. The 2nd section deals with factors affecting the relation between FP and reaction time (RT): (a) the modality, intensity, probability, and duration of the warning signal and reaction stimulus (RS) and (b) the speed-accuracy trade-off. It is suggested that the S's expectancy (momentary probability of the immediate delivery of the RS) is the most important determinant of the preparation to respond to the RS at any moment during a trial and, hence, of RT. Many factors exert their influence on preparation through their effect on expectancy. Other factors have a direct influence on preparation: short-term exhaustion and fatigue, immediate arousal evoked by intense auditory stimuli, the S's stimulus criterion, the speed-accuracy trade-off, and fluctuation in motor preparedness owing to inaccuracies in the control of motor preparation. (41/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1981 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: foreperiod variables including duration & regularity & range & distribution & preceding foreperiods, simple auditory & visual RT, literature review
Correspondence Address: Niemi, P.; U TurkuFinland

Title: Tests of differences in p levels as tests of differences in effect sizes
Authors with affiliations: Hsu, L.M., Fairleigh Dickinson U, Teaneck
Abstract: R. Rosenthal and D. Rubin (see record 1979-32732-001) proposed tests for contrasts of p values reported in independent studies. The present author indicates that although for studies of equal size these tests may be used to test hypotheses about equality of J. Cohen's (1977) effect sizes, for studies of unequal size these tests are generally not robust. An alternative test is described that may be used to test hypotheses of equality of Cohen's effect sizes in the case of unequal-sized studies. (2 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: tests of differences in "p" levels as tests of differences in effect size
Correspondence Address: Hsu, L.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson U, Teaneck

Title: Monte Carlo studies of Levy's "nonparametric large-sample pairwise comparisons"
Authors with affiliations: Wike, E.L., U Kansas, Lawrence, United States; Church, J.D.
Abstract: The Type I error rates for K. J. Levy's (see record 1979-25161-001) nonparametric pairwise tests for 1- and 2-way layouts were found in 2 Monte Carlo studies. In Exp I, Levy's test was contrasted with the Wilcoxon rank-sum test at α = .05 and .01. Exp II compared Levy's test with the Wilcoxon signed-ranks, sign, and stepped-down sign tests at α = .05 and .01. Both Levy tests displayed excellent experimentwise error rates. But when Levy's tests were used as "protected" tests after a significant overall Kruskal-Wallis or Friedman test, their experimentwise error rates were inferior to the Wilcoxon rank-sum test in the 1-way layout and to the Wilcoxon signed-ranks and the stepped-down sign tests in the 2-way layout. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Monte Carlo studies, Levy's nonparametric large sample pairwise tests
Correspondence Address: Wike, E.L.; U Kansas, Lawrence, United States

Title: Significance tests and goodness of fit in the analysis of covariance structures
Affiliations: U California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bentler, P.M., U California, Los Angeles, United States; Bonett, D.G.
Abstract: Factor analysis, path analysis, structural equation modeling, and related multivariate statistical methods are based on maximum likelihood or generalized least squares estimation developed for covariance structure models (CSMs). Large-sample theory provides a chi-square goodness-of-fit test for comparing a model (M) against a general alternative M based on correlated variables. It is suggested that this comparison is insufficient for M evaluation. A general null M based on modified independence among variables is proposed as an additional reference point for the statistical and scientific evaluation of CSMs. Use of the null M in the context of a procedure that sequentially evaluates the statistical necessity of various sets of parameters places statistical methods in covariance structure analysis into a more complete framework. The concepts of ideal Ms and pseudo chi-square tests are introduced, and their roles in hypothesis testing are developed. The importance of supplementing statistical evaluation with incremental fit indices associated with the comparison of hierarchical Ms is also emphasized. Normed and nonnormed fit indices are developed and illustrated. (43 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: significance tests & goodness of fit, analysis of covariance structures
Correspondence Address: Bentler, P.M.; U California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Comparison of two methods for testing linear hypotheses in tables of proportions
Authors with affiliations: Steiger, J.H., U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: Two tests for interaction effects in 2-2 proportion tables were compared theoretically and empirically. One method was based on the traditional use of the normal approximation to the binomial distribution, whereas the 2nd, suggested by E. J. Langer and R. P. Abelson (see record 1973-04425-001), used the "arc sine transform." Method 1, as suspected, performed most poorly under conditions (small N, large or small p) in which the binomial departed markedly from the normal. However, the statistic performed better than generally expected and could be used safely with small to moderate samples. Method 2 was found to be seriously biased, essentially because a nonlinear transform was applied to a linear hypothesis. Moreover, even when conditions were optimal for its use, Method 2 failed to outperform the more traditional test. It is argued that the use of Method 2 should be discontinued. (3 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: tests for interaction effects in tables of proportions
Correspondence Address: Steiger, J.H.; U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada

Title: Iconic memory: A review and critique of the study of short-term visual storage
Authors with affiliations: Long, G.M., Villanova U
Abstract: Evaluates 5 types of experimental procedures that have been used to investigate iconic memory (IM) over the past 20 yrs: partial report, persistence of form, duration of stimulus, delay of masking effect, and successive field procedures. It is argued that in some cases these procedures are not equivalent methods for the investigation of IM and that alternate visual processes most likely underlie performance on certain tasks. To support this claim, the widely discrepant evidence concerning the effect of target energy on IM is reanalyzed in light of relative strengths and weaknesses of the various methodologies used. It is shown that the results obtained from a particular procedure, identified as especially sensitive to alternate interpretations, are consistently at odds with those obtained from theoretically purer iconic tasks. The remaining body of evidence presents a relatively integrated picture of an energy-dependent sensory trace following stimulus offset, much as predicted for a retinally based persistence phenomenon. (5 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: experimental procedures, investigation of iconic memory, literature review

Title: Biofeedback-induced control of human peripheral temperature: A critical review of literature
Affiliations: Preston Inst of Technology, Bundoora, Australia
Authors with affiliations: King, N.J., Preston Inst of Technology, Bundoora, Australia; Montgomery, R.B.
Abstract: Examines the physiology of peripheral temperature and notes several problems associated with the choice of peripheral temperature as an index of blood flow and autonomic activity. The role of peripheral temperature in psychological research is explored. Most of the experiments resulted in small-magnitude peripheral temperature control (Tc), with decreases in hand and finger skin temperature being greater than increases. Large individual differences were also found in biofeedback-induced peripheral TC. Until recent years, the research studies were weak in terms of controls for instruction effects, hypnotic suggestions, thermal imagery, and monetary incentive, which often confound biofeedback-temperature training. It is argued that, theoretically, the research in the area was shortsighted, with little attention being given to the usefulness of mediational strategies and to the question of self-control. (72 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: physiology & biofeedback control of peripheral temperature, humans, literature review
Index Keywords: article; human; psychophysiology; research; skin temperature; Biofeedback (Psychology); Human; Research; Skin Temperature
Correspondence Address: King, N.J.; Preston Inst of Technology, Bundoora, Australia

Title: Immediate perceptual response to intersensory discrepancy
Authors with affiliations: Welch, R.B., U Kansas, Lawrence, United States; Warren, D.H.
Abstract: Reviews the literature on the intersensory bias (IB) resulting when the information available to different sensory modalities is caused to be discrepant. Characteristics for which discrepant sensory information has been provided include spatial location, shape, size/length, and orientation. Stimulus variables affecting the magnitude of IB include structural and cognitive factors. Response variables affecting intersensory bias are the type and timing of the response required of Ss. Evidence on developmental trends and individual differences in the susceptibility to IB is both sparse and conflicting. Also unclear is the relationship between IB and adaptation to perceptual rearrangement. Since none of the various theories--modality precision, directed attention, and modality appropriateness--accounts for all of the intersensory discrepancy results, a new model is proposed, based on the supposition that IB is a result of an attempt by the perceptual system to maintain a perceptual experience consonant with a unitary event. (21/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus discrepancy, intersensory bias, literature review
Index Keywords: cognition; depth perception; hearing; human; orientation; pattern recognition; perception; perception disorder; proprioception; review; sensation; Auditory Perception; Cognition; Form Perception; Human; Orientation; Perception; Perceptual Distortion; Proprioception; Sensation; Size Perception; Space Perception
Correspondence Address: Welch, R.B.; U Kansas, Lawrence, United States

Title: New time-series statistic for detecting rhythmic co-occurrence in the frequency domain: The weighted coherence and its application to psychophysiological research
Authors with affiliations: Porges, S.W., U Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, United States; et al
Abstract: The relationships among physiological systems and between physiological and behavioral systems have frequently been evaluated with traditional descriptive statistics. These methods may not be sensitive to underlying rhythmic relationships. Although cross-spectral analysis provides a method for assessing rhythmic co-occurrence, it is only capable of describing the covariation of 2 systems at specific frequencies. Since physiological and behavioral systems tend not to be manifested at a constant frequency, a new statistic is described that is capable of evaluating the shared rhythmicity of 2 systems across an entire band of frequencies. (13 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: weighted coherence statistic, evaluation of rhythmic co-occurrence across frequencies
Index Keywords: animal; arousal; article; human; physiology; psychophysiology; Animal; Arousal; Human; Psychophysiology; Statistics; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.

Title: Amphetamine models of paranoid schizophrenia: An overview and elaboration of animal experimentation
Authors with affiliations: Kokkinidis, L., U Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Canada; Anisman, H.
Abstract: A review of the literature suggests that although some behaviors may be mediated by dopamine (DA) and other behaviors are largely subserved by noradrenergic mechanisms, the elicitation of a given behavior by amphetamine may be influenced by the interaction among several transmitters. It is hypothesized that behaviors that involve norepinephrine (NE) activity are stimulus bound and are related to attentional processes, whereas behaviors primarily subserved by DA appear to be motorically based. Behavioral augmentations frequently observed following repeated drug treatment are postulated to reflect alterations in DA activity, whereas the reduction of the drug's effect is ascribed to changes in attentional processes owing to variations in NE activity. The acute and chronic effects of dextro-amphetamine on attentional and arousal processes are related to current views of drug-induced psychosis in humans and to endogenous disorders. (91/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.

Title: Experimental investigation of chronic organic amnesia: A review
Authors with affiliations: Knight, R.G., U Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand; Wooles, I.G.
Abstract: Research on the locus of the deficit in amnesic patients is reviewed, and the associated methodological problems and remediation strategies are examined. Findings suggest that anterograde amnesia may result from either a failure to encode newly acquired information or a reduced ability to retrieve consolidated input, although the relative importance of the contributions of these specific impairments to amnesia is unclear. Inadequate matching of tasks within experiments and differences in S selection render between-experimental comparisons ambiguous. Organic amnesia patients are able to retain information in long-term memory; however, whether cognitive retraining strategies enhance this effect is largely unknown. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: experimental investigation, chronic organic amnesia, literature review

Title: On the use of distractors for testing recognition memory
Authors with affiliations: Wallace, W.P., U Nevada, Reno, United States
Abstract: Procedures for testing recognition memory have almost invariably required that Ss discriminate old items from new items. At the process level, recognition refers to the capacity of knowing or feeling that a given event has been experienced before. Several previous studies have used a discrimination procedure to test this capacity as a way to prevent Ss from indiscriminately claiming to recognize all test events. It is argued that valid objective tests of recognition memory can be conducted without formal discrimination-testing procedures. Testing recognition memory without distractor items on the test is a viable laboratory procedure, and it is more relevant to the basic concept of recognition memory than the standard discrimination-testing procedures. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: use of distractors & discrimination procedures, testing recognition memory
Index Keywords: article; attention; human; memory; pattern recognition; recall; Attention; Form Perception; Human; Memory; Mental Recall; Pattern Recognition, Visual

Title: The juvenile delinquent as a moral philosopher: A structural-developmental perpective
Affiliations: Georgia State U, Atlanta, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jurkovic, G.J., Georgia State U, Atlanta, United States
Abstract: Reviews structural-developmental studies of the hypothesized moral immaturity of juvenile delinquents. Despite methodological problems related to the assessment of both delinquent conduct and moral judgment, discernible trends in the data have begun to emerge. Perhaps most significant is that delinquency only moderately relates to a premoral ideological orientation. Although reliable differences between delinquent and nondelinquent youths in moral reasoning have not been demonstrated, moral judgment stage appears to covary with personality and behavioral characteristics of the delinquents themselves. Evidence also suggests that their level of moral judgment is significantly influenced by a variety of situational, motivational, and attitudinal variables. In light of these results, distinctions are drawn (following J. Flavell in T. Mischel, 1974) between underlying sociomoral capabilities and the tendency to exercise and apply these capabilities. Factors mediating various components of the moral judgment process in juvenile offenders are discussed. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: morality & moral development, juvenile delinquents, literature review
Index Keywords: adolescent; article; child; child development; human; juvenile delinquency; morality; philosophy; psychological aspect; Adolescent; Child; Child Development; Human; Juvenile Delinquency; Morals; Philosophy

Title: On estimating the diagnosticity of eyewitness nonidentifications
Authors with affiliations: Wells, G.L., U Alberta, Edmonton, Canada; Lindsay, R.C.
Abstract: Questions the criminal justice system's practice of treating eyewitness lineup identifications (IDs) of suspects (SUs) as highly informative while treating nonidentifications (NIDs) (i.e., no choice responses or choices of foils) as uninformative. A Bayesian model of information gain is used to mathematically prove that (a) if an eyewitness ID of an SU increases the probability that the SU is the criminal, then an NID must decrease the probability that the SU is the criminal; and (b) the relative diagnosticity of IDs vs NIDs is determined by the probability of obtaining an ID vs NID, with NIDs being more diagnostic if they are relatively less frequent than IDs. An application of the model to previously published data shows NIDs to be more than 150% as diagnostic as IDs regarding the probability that the SU is the criminal. A breakdown of NIDs into 2 types, eyewitness choices of a lineup foil vs no-choice decisions, suggests that the latter is more informative than the former regarding the probability that the SU is innocent. Cognitive mechanisms that may be responsible for criminal justice investigators discounting of NIDs are discussed in relation to research on human judgment. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: diagnostic validity of identifications vs nonidentifications of lineup suspects, eyewitnesses
Correspondence Address: Wells, G.L.; U Alberta, Edmonton, Canada

Authors: Nesselroade J.R., Stigler S.M., Baltes P.B.
Title: Regression toward the mean and the study of change
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State U, Coll of Human Development, University Park
Authors with affiliations: Nesselroade, J.R., Pennsylvania State U, Coll of Human Development, University Park; Stigler, S.M.; Baltes, P.B.
Abstract: Examines regression effects in longitudinal sequences of observations by formulating expectations (Es) for later observations conditioned on an initial selection score value. The Es are developed for several variations of classical test theory and autocorrelation models. Es based on the general concept of regression are seen not only to depart from those depicted in the psychometric lore but to vary considerably from one underlying model to another, particularly when moving from the 2-occasion to a multiple-occasion measurement framework. Regression toward the mean is not a ubiquitous phenomenon, nor does it always continue across occasions. It is necessary to specify the characteristics of model assumptions to understand the when, how, and extent of regression toward the mean. Past interpretations have been incomplete and to an extent incorrect because they focused largely on a limited circumstance: 2-occasions of measurement and simplexlike correlation matrices. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: regression toward mean & study of change
Correspondence Address: Nesselroade, J.R.; Pennsylvania State U, , University Park

Title: Sex roles and dirty word usage: A review of the literature and a reply to Haas
Authors with affiliations: Jay, T.B., North Adams State Coll
Abstract: A. Haas (see record 1979-28136-001) found that little evidence exists to distinguish between males' and females' use of dirty words. In contrast, the present author's review found several empirical studies comparing the sexes. It is argued that establishing whether differences exist does not necessarily require recording colloquial speech, nor would the phenomenon have to be studied entirely outside of the laboratory setting. (41 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: sex differences, dirty word usage, literature review & criticism of A. Haas's study
Correspondence Address: Jay, T.B.; North Adams State Coll

Title: Are women more responsive than men to the young? A review of developmental and situational variables
Affiliations: National Inst of Child Health and Human Development, Bethesda, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berman, P.W., National Inst of Child Health and Human Development, Bethesda, MD, United States
Abstract: Reviews studies that compared responses of male and female children and adults to infants, young children, baby animals, baby cries, or pictures of the young. Males' and females' responses and therefore sex differences varied greatly depending on the physical and social qualities of the situation, the response required, and the Ss' experimental or prior role relationship with the young. Demographic comparisons showed considerable variability between cultures. Within the American culture, responsiveness changed throughout the life span for both sexes, but these changes do not reflect life span hormonal changes, at least in any simple, straightforward manner. Implications for a theory of the social determinants of responsiveness to the young are discussed. (21/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: age & sex & cultural & situational differences, responses to infants & young children & baby animals & cries & pictures, children & adults, literature review
Correspondence Address: Berman, P.W.; National Inst of Child Health and Human Development, Bethesda, MD, United States

Title: Power of the multivariate analysis of variance tests
Authors with affiliations: Stevens, J.P., U Cincinnati
Abstract: Demonstrates that the power of the multivariate tests with small-to-moderate group and effect sizes is poor, as is true for univariate ANOVA. A table is given for 2-group multivariate ANOVA and a table for the 3- and 5-variable cases gives combinations of univariate effect sizes that will yield overall (multivariate) effect sizes. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: power of multivariate ANOVA tests
Correspondence Address: Stevens, J.P.

Authors: Keselman H.J., Games P.A., Rogan J.C.
Title: Type I and Type II errors in simultaneous and two-stage multiple comparison procedures
Authors with affiliations: Keselman, H.J., U Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada; Games, P.A.; Rogan, J.C.
Abstract: Responds to T. A. Ryan (see record 1980-29331-001) by emphasizing and demonstrating the usual inferential trade-off between protecting Type I and protecting Type II errors for multiple comparison procedures. Simultaneous test procedures are preferred, but it is felt that there are types of investigations in which an experimenter may reasonably choose Fisher's least significant difference 2-stage procedure. It is also noted that the decision to guard one type of error more than the other is subjective and not mathematical. Psychological researchers should consider setting the overall rate of Type I errors at a value significantly larger than .05 for certain types of investigations. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Type I & II errors in multiple comparison procedures, reply to criticism of T. A. Ryan
Correspondence Address: Keselman, H.J.; U Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada

Authors: Kaner H.C., Mohanty S.G., Lyons J.C.
Title: Critical values of the Kolmogorov-Smirnov one-sample tests
Authors with affiliations: Kaner, H.C., McMaster U, Hamilton, Canada; Mohanty, S.G.; Lyons, J.C.
Abstract: Corrects a prevalent misuse of the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test for goodness of fit by providing new critical values for the computational form of the test most often used by psychologists (Dn maximum). Existing tables for the test assume a different computational form (Dn supremum). The common use of the Dn-maximum version with the Dn-supremum table results in a test that is overly conservative. The consequences of using the Dn-maximum computational form with its correct critical values are discussed. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: critical values of Kolmogorov Smirnov one-sample test
Correspondence Address: Kaner, H.C.; McMaster U, Hamilton, Canada

Title: Comment on "Combining results of independent studies"
Authors with affiliations: Vatza, E.J., Lehigh U; et al
Abstract: Maintains that R. Rosenthal (see record 1979-22692-001) erred in his discussion of 2 of the various techniques he reviewed. The errors, which involve confusion over what constitutes a one-tailed test, are explained and corrected. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).

Title: Comment on "Protecting the overall rate of Type I errors for pairwise comparisons with an omnibus test statistic": or Fisher's two-stage strategy still does not work
Authors with affiliations: Ryan, T.A., Cornell U
Abstract: H. J. Keselman et al (see record 1979-30184-001) considered ways in which the Fisher 2-stage strategy for multiple comparisons can be strengthened against heterogeneous variance or unequal sample sizes. The Fisher strategy is still unacceptable, even with these improvements, because the actual experiment-wise error rate can still be much higher than the nominal value. (5 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Fisher 2-stage strategy for multiple comparisons, criticism of article by H. J. Keselman et al
Correspondence Address: Ryan, T.A.

Title: Statistical approaches to the correction of correlational bias
Authors with affiliations: Kenny, D.A., U Connecticut, Storrs, United States; Berman, J.S.
Abstract: Examines the effectiveness of a mean rating strategy, in which correlations are derived from ratings pooled across a number of observers, and also presents a prophecy formula for determining the number of raters needed. Analysis indicated that the success of mean ratings in correcting for correlational bias depends on the reliability of ratings, the number of raters, and the differences between true and assumed correlations between traits. A more efficient correlational strategy that not only allows statistical correction for correlational bias but also permits tests of various hypotheses concerning the rating process is also discussed. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: rating reliability & number of raters & true vs assumed trait correlations, correction for correlational bias
Correspondence Address: Kenny, D.A.; U Connecticut, Storrs, United States

Title: On telling tails when combining results of independent studies
Authors with affiliations: Rosenthal, R., Harvard U
Abstract: Illustrates the use of one-tailed tests in combining results of independent probabilities. The distinction is made between the use of the tails of (a) those distributions with lower bounds of zero and (b) those that are symmetrical about zero. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: use of 1-tailed tests in combining results of independent studies
Correspondence Address: Rosenthal, R.

Title: The smoking problem: A review of the research and theory in behavioral risk modification
Authors with affiliations: Leventhal, H., U Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Cleary, P.D.
Abstract: Reviews findings and theoretical implications of studies concerned with initiation, maintenance, and therapy of cigarette smoking in children and adults. The following conclusions are offered: (a) Recent increases in success rates may be due to changes in the social environment that multiply the action of previously unsuccessful procedures, (b) current interventions are based on communication and behavioral models that ignore features unique to smoking, (c) methodological refinements of current interventions are unlikely to increase success rates significantly, (d) prevention studies should be directed toward critical steps in the developmental history of smoking (e.g., preventing initial attempts and retarding regular usage), and (e) studies of cessation and withdrawal must consider findings and theories of nicotine dependence. Also discussed are the development of craving and its elimination. (9 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.

Title: Visual masking: Mechanisms and theories
Affiliations: U Illinois Medical Ctr, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Felsten, G., U Illinois Medical Ctr, Chicago, United States; Wasserman, G.S.
Abstract: Two complementary interpretations of visual masking exist, each based on an analogy with a nonneural system. Peripheral integrative masking is said to occur when masking is energy dependent, by analogy with photographic emulsions. Central interruptive masking is said to occur when masking is time dependent, by analogy with digital computers. Psychophysical studies have tested a variety of other properties of the integrative-interruptive dichotomy beyond time vs energy dependence; these tests have generally supported the integrative interpretation. Psychobiological studies have shown that neural integration can produce time-dependent effects in a masking paradigm. Data lead to this harmonization of the masking problem: Different features (sensory codes) of identical neural responses differ in their energy or time dependence. Since the sensory code is task dependent, task variation can cause a single integrative mechanism to lead to either time or energy dependent behavior. Thus, the variety and complexity of the behaviors in masking studies are a joint consequence of the variety of sensory codes and the complexity of neural integration. (78 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: mechanisms & theories of visual masking, literature review
Index Keywords: animal; article; human; perception; psychophysics; vision; Animal; Human; Perceptual Masking; Psychophysics; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Felsten, G.; U Illinois Medical Ctr, Chicago, United States

Title: Spatial relationships among epidemiological and community populations
Authors with affiliations: Lewis, M.S., U Texas, Austin, United States; Brockett, P.
Abstract: An important and difficult problem in community and epidemiological psychology is the analysis of the geographic association between members of one population (e.g., schizophrenics) and those of another (e.g., suspected etiological factors). The present article introduces a new statistic that can be of value in the analysis of such geographic interactions and applies it to the geographic distribution of suicides in a large city. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: analysis of geographic interactions among epidemiological & community populations

Title: Critical review of research on psychotherapy outcome with adolescents: 1967-1977
Affiliations: U Nebraska Medical Ctr, Nebraska Psychiatric Inst, Omaha, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tramontana, M.G., U Nebraska Medical Ctr, Nebraska Psychiatric Inst, Omaha, United States
Abstract: Describes and critically evaluates studies on individual, group, and family therapy that were published largely from 1967 through 1977. Of 33 independent investigations, 5 are judged as exemplary in methodological scope and rigor. Although methodological deficiencies abound, the greater weight of available evidence on adolescents does point toward the superiority of psychotherapy over no-therapy conditions, with the median rate of positive outcome with psychotherapy being approximately 75%, compared with a rate of 39% without psychotherapy. Little is presently known, however, regarding the effects of specific patient, therapist, and process variables on adolescent therapy outcome. (56 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: research on psychotherapy outcomes with adolescents, literature review
Index Keywords: adolescent; article; human; methodology; psychotherapy; research; treatment outcome; Adolescent; Human; Outcome and Process Assessment (Health Care); Psychotherapy; Research
Correspondence Address: Tramontana, M.G.; U Nebraska Medical Ctr, , Omaha, United States

Title: Quantitative indices of perceptual constancy
Authors with affiliations: Myers, A.K., U California, Riverside, United States
Abstract: The Brunswik ratio, the oldest and most widely known index of perceptual constancy, has serious deficiencies that make it unsuitable for its intended use. There exist 2 different and inconsistent computational versions of the Brunswik ratio, depending on which stimulus is identified as the standard and which the comparison. It is concluded that the Thouless ratio best satisfies the requirements of a single numerical index of perceptual constancy. Alternative forms of the Thouless ratio are described, as well as applications related to psychophysical scaling procedures. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Brunswik vs Thouless ratios as indices of perceptual constancy
Index Keywords: article; human; model; psychophysics; vision; Human; Models, Psychological; Psychophysics; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Myers, A.K.; U California, Riverside, United States

Title: Psychological effects of imprisonment on confined individuals
Authors with affiliations: Bukstel, L.H., U South Carolina; Kilmann, P.R.
Abstract: Reviews 90 experimental studies that examined the psychological effects of imprisonment on performance, personality, and attitudinal variables. Analysis revealed that the studies had many methodological problems, including the use of inadequate research designs and unsystematic sampling procedures. The types of Ss and time periods used varied widely, thus making a comparison of the findings, at times, difficult. Results suggested that imprisonment is not harmful to all individuals: Some persons deteriorated in response to confinement, other persons improved their functioning, and still others showed no appreciable change. A complex interaction of factors including individual difference variables, institutional orientation, degree of crowding, phase of sentence, and peer group affiliation seems to influence an individual's response to confinement. Findings also have implications for current correctional controversies such as the "nothing works" issue and the relative value of determinate vs indeterminate sentencing procedures. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: imprisonment, psychological effects on performance & personality & attitudinal variables, prisoners, literature review
Index Keywords: article; attitude; cognition; human; perception; personality; prisoner; psychological aspect; Attitude; Cognition; Human; Perception; Personality; Prisoners

Title: Infant operant conditioning and its implications for early intervention
Affiliations: U Nijmegen, Inst of Orthopedagogics, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Lancioni, G.E., U Nijmegen, Inst of Orthopedagogics, Netherlands
Abstract: Reviews and groups studies on infant operant conditioning according to their different procedures (i.e., free operant, discrete trial with 1 discriminative stimulus, controlled operant with 1 discriminative stimulus, discrete trial with 2 or more discriminative stimuli, controlled operant with 2 or more discriminative stimuli, and unrestricted operant with 2 or more discriminative stimuli). Implications of conditioning principles for early intervention are discussed in terms of reinforcement, prompting and shaping, reduction of deviant responses, biobehavioral state, and discrimination training. (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: operant conditioning & early intervention, infants, literature review
Index Keywords: article; behavior disorder; child psychology; discrimination learning; human; infant; instrumental conditioning; psychological aspect; Child Behavior Disorders; Child Psychology; Conditioning, Operant; Discrimination Learning; Human; Infant; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.
Correspondence Address: Lancioni, G.E.; U Nijmegen, Netherlands

Title: Maximum-likelihood estimation in common factor analysis: A cautionary note
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, D.N., U Western Ontario, London, Canada; Chan, D.W.
Abstract: Offers some perspectives on the application of certain modern techniques, particularly maximum-likelihood estimation, for fitting the common factor analysis model to empirical data. Four general cautions are expressed: (a) Results from alternative factoring methods are typically similar, (b) commonly encountered improper numerical solutions pose serious problems for interpretation, (c) problems are encountered in interpreting significance tests, and (d) cross-replication is needed. A judicious choice among alternative models is recommended rather than blind application of present maximum-likelihood-based techniques for evaluating the fit of a restricted model, such as the common factor model. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: use of maximum likelihood estimation in common factor analysis
Correspondence Address: Jackson, D.N.; U Western Ontario, London, Canada

Title: Estimating false alarms and missed events from interobserver agreement: A rationale
Authors with affiliations: Kaye, K., U Chicago
Abstract: In the analysis of temporal, sequential, or contingent relations among events within sessions, the observers' or coders' false-alarm rate and missed-event rate are more useful than coefficients of interobserver agreement as indices of reliability. False-alarm and missed-event probabilities can be estimated from comparisons of 2 codings, either in the fixed-unit situation or when behavior has been coded in continuous time. Complex problems, such as those that arise when rates are computed in the context of 2 or more mutually exclusive continuous states, can often be reduced to a simple model, so long as investigators keep in mind the precise meaning of the reliability indices they use. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimation of false alarm & missed event probabilities, analysis of relations among events within sessions
Correspondence Address: Kaye, K.

Title: Fluid and crystallized intelligences: Two fanciful concepts
Authors with affiliations: Guilford, J.P., U Southern California
Abstract: Questions the validity of fluid and crystallized intelligence (gf and gc, respectively) as promoted by J. L. Horn and R. B. Cattell (see record 1966-13188-001). Gf is said to be more largely determined by heredity and gc more by environmental conditions. Horn and Cattell cite factor analyses to support these 2 abilities, which they regard as 2nd-order factors, demonstrated from intercorrelations of scores representing 1st-order factors. In at least 1 of these analyses, the tested Ss varied widely in age and education and other conditions that are likely to bias intercorrelations of test scores. The 2 obtained factors purported to represent gf and gc could thus have been spurious. In other analyses with better controls, however, 2 such factors did also appear, with 2 or 3 in addition. However, the present author interprets these factors to be 2nd- or 3rd-order abilities differing along the lines of the categories of the present author's structure-of-intellect model. The fanciful names do not appear to represent valid constructs. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: fluid & crystallized intelligence, criticism of concepts promoted by J. L. Horn & R. B. Cattell
Correspondence Address: Guilford, J.P.

Title: Environmental cognition
Authors with affiliations: Evans, G.W., U California, Irvine
Abstract: Reviews research on human cognition in real, everyday settings. Cognitive mapping literature is organized into 5 empirical categories: age, familiarity, gender, class and culture, and physical components of settings. Methodological and conceptual issues in the environmental cognition literature are discussed, emphasizing problems with hand-drawn sketch map methodologies and theoretical ambiguities about the cognitive-mapping process. In particular, the lack of integration of pertinent cognitive research with the environmental psychology literature on cognitive mapping is noted. Potential applications of environmental cognition work to architecture, planning, and education are discussed. (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: environmental cognition & cognitive mapping, literature review
Correspondence Address: Evans, G.W.; U California, Irvine

Authors: Saal F.E., Downey R.G., Lahey M.A.
Title: Rating the ratings: Assessing the psychometric quality of rating data
Affiliations: Kansas State U, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Saal, F.E., Kansas State U, Manhattan, United States; Downey, R.G.; Lahey, M.A.
Abstract: Reviews research that is concerned with evaluating the psychometric qualities of data in the form of ratings (rating errors) and that has been plagued with conceptual and operational confusion and inconsistency. Following a brief historical survey, inconsistencies in definitions, quantifications, and methodologies are documented in a review of more than 20 relevant articles published in Journal of Applied Psychology, Organizational Behavior and Human Performance, and Personnel Psychology (1975-1977). Empirical implications of these inconsistencies are discussed, and a revised typology of rating criteria, combined with a multivariate analytic approach, is suggested. (65 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: evaluation of psychometric qualities of rating data, literature review
Correspondence Address: Saal, F.E.; Kansas State U, Manhattan, United States

Title: Integration and generalization of kappas for multiple raters
Authors with affiliations: Conger, A.J., Purdue U
Abstract: J. A. Cohen's kappa (1960) for measuring agreement between 2 raters, using a nominal scale, has been extended for use with multiple raters by R. J. Light (1971) and J. L. Fleiss (1971). In the present article, these indices are analyzed and reformulated in terms of agreement statistics based on all pairs of raters. It has been argued that simultaneous agreement among all raters could provide an alternative basis for measuring multiple-rater agreement; however, agreement among raters can actually be considered to be an arbitrary choice along a continuum ranging from agreement for a pair of raters to agreement among all raters. Using this generalized concept of g-wise agreement, multiple-rater kappas are extended, interrelated, and illustrated. (4 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: integration & generalization of kappas, multiple raters
Correspondence Address: Conger, A.J.

Title: Vote-counting methods in research synthesis
Authors with affiliations: Hedges, L.V., Stanford U; Olkin, I.
Abstract: Reviews of research usually rely on counts of the number of times the treatment group mean exceeds the control group mean by an amount that is statistically significant. The treatment is said to have a positive effect if the proportion of such positive significant results is large. This procedure is shown to have extremely low power for the combination of treatment-effect sizes and sample sizes usually found in social science research. Surprisingly, the power of this procedure decreases as the number of studies reviewed increases. Three alternative counting procedures that permit estimation of the standardized mean difference between treatment and control groups (effect size) are described. Methods for obtaining confidence intervals for the effect size are also presented. For 1 procedure, the effect size can be estimated even when the sample consists only of studies that have statistically significant results. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimation of standardized mean difference between treatment & control groups
Correspondence Address: Hedges, L.V.

Title: A critique of cross-lagged correlation
Authors with affiliations: Rogosa, D., Stanford U School of Education
Abstract: Comments that cross-lagged correlation (CLc) is not a useful procedure for the analysis of longitudinal panel data. In particular, the difference between CLCs is not a sound basis for causal inference. Demonstrations of the failure of CLC are based mainly on results for the 2-wave, 2-variable longitudinal panel design. Extensions of these results to panels with multiple waves and multiple measures reveal additional problems; each 2-wave snapshot did not yield dependable results. Taken together, the 2-wave analyses were often contradictory and misleading. (33 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: use of cross-lagged correlation for analysis of longitudinal panel data
Correspondence Address: Rogosa, D.; Stanford U School of Education

Title: On the relationship of reliability to statistical power
Authors with affiliations: Sutcliffe, J.P., U Sydney, Australia
Abstract: Relations among reliability of difference, reliability of the dependent variable, and power are made explicit in terms of true and error variance to enable critical evaluation of some recent contentious claims. J. E. Overall and J. A. Woodward's (see record 1975-08623-001) "paradox" that power increases as reliability of difference decreases is shown to result from 2 confusions: that of variance ratio with the property of reliability of a measuring procedure and that of indirect with direct relationship. The inverse relationship between magnitudes of variance ratio and power that holds for the conditions set by Overall and Woodward is actually an indirect consequence of variation that by stipulation is not variation in reliability as such. The paradoxical relationship is spurious. At the same time, as J. L. Fleiss (1976) argued, unreliability proper diminishes power. Thus the paradox is resolved. Although it is typically impractical to vary either true or error variance, an experimenter can offset the detrimental effects of unreliability of measurement on power by averaging, after collecting more than 1 observation per S per treatment. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: relationships between reliability of difference & dependent variable & power
Correspondence Address: Sutcliffe, J.P.; U SydneyAustralia

Title: Comparing nonparallel regression lines
Authors with affiliations: Rogosa, D., Stanford U School of Education
Abstract: Presents a comprehensive strategy for the statistical comparison of within-group regressions that is suitable for both parallel and nonparallel regression lines. New results are obtained from 2 groups of Ss, and new interpretations are formulated for standard statistical procedures such as analysis of covariance. New procedures for comparing regressions are proposed and illustrated. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: statistical comparison of parallel & nonparallel regression lines
Correspondence Address: Rogosa, D.; Stanford U School of Education

Title: Exposure learning in animals
Authors with affiliations: Hall, G., U York, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Reviews experimental studies (using animal Ss) that investigated the effects of prior exposure to a pair of stimuli on subsequent visual discrimination learning. The bulk of these experiments used young rats as Ss, with stimulus exposure taking place in the home cage over a long period of time. When such procedures produce transfer to later learning, it is usually positive. Also reviewed are related experiments that differ in their procedural details. In most of these studies, later learning is found to be retarded. An attempt is made to isolate the critical feature or features of an exposure-learning experiment that determines whether transfer will be positive or negative, and possible theoretical interpretations of the empirical generalizations that emerge are also considered. (66 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: prior exposure to pair of stimuli, subsequent visual discrimination learning, animals, literature review
Correspondence Address: Hall, G.; U York, England, United Kingdom

Title: In defense of peer assessment: A rebuttal to Brief's critique
Authors with affiliations: Kane, J.S.; Lawler, E.E.
Abstract: Responds to A. P. Brief's (see record 1980-26779-001) critique of the present authors' (see record 1979-10110-001) review of peer assessment methods. Brief focuses on treatment of the applicability of peer assessment, the utility of peer nominations, and the utility of peer ratings. The present authors show that their treatments of these subjects were both consistent with the article's scope and properly conservative in the conclusions that were drawn. These considerations, along with the conceptual deficiencies that are shown to afflict several of Brief's comments, effectively rebut Brief's critique. (4 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: review of peer assessment methods, response to A. P. Brief's critique

Authors: Stoline M.R., Huitema B.E., Mitchell B.T.
Title: Intervention time-series model with different pre- and postintervention first-order autoregressive parameters
Authors with affiliations: Stoline, M.R., Western Michigan U; Huitema, B.E.; Mitchell, B.T.
Abstract: Intervention time-series models (ITM) have been used in the behavioral, physical, and social sciences to statistically evaluate the change in the level of a variable Z after an intervention event has occurred when it is assumed that Z is observed over several equally spaced intervals of time. The intervening event may also affect the time-series structure itself. The present article introduces and discusses an ITM that includes distinct pre- and postintervention 1st-order autoregressive parameters. The ITM was used to assess the effect of a pilot project on decriminalizing drunkenness by analyzing the change in 60 seasonally adjusted weekly drunkenness arrests between pre- and postprogram implementation periods. Certain checks that use the estimated and partial autocorrelations of the residual fitted model must be satisfied before use of this ITM is recommended. (8 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: extension of time-series intervention model including different pre- & postintervention 1st order autoregressive parameters, pilot project on decriminalizing drunkenness
Correspondence Address: Stoline, M.R.

Title: Note on standardized regression estimators
Affiliations: U Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bobko, P., U Maryland, College Park, United States; Schemmer, F.M.
Abstract: Routine standardization of sample data can lead to the loss of theoretically important properties of regression estimators; e.g., standardization of sample data results in regression weights that are biased estimators of population parameters. Thus, commonly accepted theoretical statements about least squares regression estimators do not apply to standardized estimators. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: standardization of sample data, properties of least squares regression estimators
Correspondence Address: Bobko, P.; U Maryland, College Park, United States

Title: Bridging moral cognition and moral action: A critical review of the literature
Authors with affiliations: Blasi, A., U Massachusetts, Boston
Abstract: Discusses conceptual and empirical issues concerning the relations between moral reasoning and moral action. Two opposite views of the relations between moral cognition and moral action are described; one is an essentially irrational view that emphasizes need and action tendencies, while the other considers moral functioning as essentially rational. Their contrasting assumptions and implications are clarified. Available empirical literature is reviewed; research relating moral reasoning to delinquency, honesty, altruism, conformity, and other real-life moral behaviors is summarized, with special attention given to problems of design, measurement, and interpretation. Although overall these studies seem to support the cognitive-developmental perspective, this support needs to be qualified and interpreted in each area. At a more general level, the importance of clarifying the meaning of consistency between moral cognition and moral action and the need for a process approach to research in this area are emphasized. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: cognitive developmental perspective on relations between moral cognition & action, literature review
Correspondence Address: Blasi, A.; U Massachusetts, Boston

Title: Peer assessment revisited: A brief comment on Kane and Lawler
Affiliations: New York U, Graduate School of Business
Authors with affiliations: Brief, A.P., New York U, Graduate School of Business
Abstract: Critiques J. S. Kane and E. E. Lawler's (see record 1979-10110-001) review of peer assessment research. Kane and Lawler tend to overstate the case for peer assessment in general and for the peer rating method in particular, while they understate the case for the peer nomination method. Evidence to support these contentions is presented. (2 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: psychometric properties of peer assessment methods, critique of review by J. S. Kane & E. E. Lawler
Correspondence Address: Brief, A.P.; New York U,

Title: Importance of measurement theory, error theory, and experimental design for testing the significance of interactions
Affiliations: U South Carolina, Social and Behavioral Sciences Lab, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Busemeyer, J.R., U South Carolina, Social and Behavioral Sciences Lab, Colombia
Abstract: The problem of interpreting statistical interactions occurs because usually it is safe to assume only that a monotonic relation exists between the dependent measure and the psychological construct being measured (i.e., the dependent measure is an ordinal level scale). If a monotonic rescaling of the dependent measure can eliminate the interaction effect, then one must question the psychological importance of the effect. Two methods have been developed that can test whether a significant interaction is present for all monotonic scale transformations. Before these methods (functional measurement and conjoint measurement) can be evaluated, it is necessary to (a) formalize the conceptual model being tested in these situations, (b) identify the type of error theory assumed by the statistical test, and (c) consider the type of experimental design used. The application of either the functional measurement method or the conjoint measurement method depends on all of these points. (26 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: measurement theory & error theory & experimental design, testing significance of statistical interactions
Correspondence Address: Busemeyer, J.R.; U South Carolina, Colombia

Title: Reevaluation of mechanisms that mediate brain differences between enriched and impoverished animals
Affiliations: National Inst of Environmental Health Sciences, Lab of Behavioral and Neurological Toxicology, Research Triangle Park, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Uphouse, L., National Inst of Environmental Health Sciences, Lab of Behavioral and Neurological Toxicology, Research Triangle Park, NC, United States
Abstract: Discusses the roles of differential rates of maturation, stress, and hormonal activities as they contribute to brain differences between enriched and impoverished animals. Processes associated with such theoretical mechanisms have been assumed to be unsatisfactory in explaining enrichment-impoverishment differences, and as a consequence, investigators have resorted to such conceptual explanations as "learning," "arousal," and "novelty." The data leading to the rejection of processes associated with maturation, stress, and hormonal activites are reviewed, and the conclusion to disregard such potential mechanisms is questioned. (44 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: reevaluation of maturational vs hormonal vs stress mechanisms of brain differences, enriched vs impoverished animals
