Correspondence Address: Uphouse, L.; National Inst of Environmental Health Sciences, , Research Triangle Park, NC, United States

Title: Aftereffects of stress on human performance and social behavior: A review of research and theory
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, S., U Oregon
Abstract: A review of experimental and correlational studies suggests that the aftereffects of stress on performance are due to a wide range of unpredictable, uncontrollable stressors including noise, electric shock, and bureaucratic stress. These effects are not limited to stressful situations that involve a lack of predictability and controllability over a distracting stimulus; they can also be induced by increased task demand. Interventions that increase personal control and/or stressor predictability are effective in reducing poststressor effects. There is also evidence for poststimulation effects on social behavior which generally involve an insensitivity toward others following stressor exposure. Studies of exposure to environmental stressors in naturalistic settings report effects similar to those found in laboratory settings. Several theories (e.g., psychic cost, learned helplessness, arousal) are examined. Some receive more support than others, but it is concluded that the reliability and generality of poststimulation effects have many causes. (86 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: aftereffects of stress, human performance & social behavior, review of research & theory
Index Keywords: achievement; adaptive behavior; arousal; article; human; mental stress; psychological aspect; Achievement; Adaptation, Psychological; Arousal; Human; Stress, Psychological; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.
Correspondence Address: Cohen, S.

Title: Review of social-cognitive problem-solving interventions with children
Authors with affiliations: Urbain, E.S., U Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; Kendall, P.C.
Abstract: Reviews training studies of interpersonal problem solving, family problem solving, verbally mediated self-control applied to social behavior, and social perspective taking with children. Treatment procedures and outcome data are examined. Although some encouraging results have been reported, the need for assessments of behavioral adjustment, better control group procedures, and more long-term follow-up reports is noted. Specific deficits in social-cognitive abilities, the similarities across different training programs, and the active treatment ingredients in multifaceted training programs should be examined. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: training studies of interpersonal & family problem solving & verbally mediated self control & social perspective taking interventions with children, literature review
Index Keywords: adolescent; article; behavior disorder; child; cognition; female; human; male; preschool child; problem solving; social adaptation; Adolescent; Child; Child Behavior Disorders; Child, Preschool; Cognition; Female; Human; Male; Problem Solving; Social Adjustment

Title: Measurement of individual differences in intraindividual changes
Affiliations: Rutgers U, Ctr of Alcohol Studies, Piscataway
Authors with affiliations: Labouvie, E.W., Rutgers U, Ctr of Alcohol Studies, Piscataway
Abstract: Considers the utility difference scores as measures of differential intraindividual change in the context of a multivariate approach to the concepts of structure and structural change. The notion of congeneric test scores is applied simultaneously to interindividual differences observed at 2 successive points in time and to corresponding individual difference scores. Tests with congeneric scores on each of 2 occasions are neither necessary nor sufficient to yield congeneric difference scores, and vice versa. Consequently, it is possible to distinguish among psychometric, edumetric, and complete equivalence of sets of tests in relation to underlying concepts. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: multivariate approach to measurement of interindividual differences & differential intraindividual changes
Correspondence Address: Labouvie, E.W.

Title: Work and nonwork: A review of models, methods, and findings
Affiliations: Flinders U of South Australia, School of Social Science, Bedford Park
Authors with affiliations: Kabanoff, B., Flinders U of South Australia, School of Social Science, Bedford Park
Abstract: Examines 3 theories of work/leisure relations--compensation, generalization, and segmentation. All have received some support, but the present review indicates that much of the available research evidence is constrained by conceptual and methodological problems. Paradigms for describing work/leisure patterns are reviewed, and it is concluded that most of these are more suitable for classifying leisure definitions than for guiding empirical research. Research in this field requires objective definitions of attributes common across life spheres. A task-based description of work and nonwork is discussed, and its research utility is illustrated. Future research should describe different work/leisure patterns, the processes underlying these patterns, and the life consequences associated with different patterns. (98 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theories of work/leisure patterns & expansion of research to attributes across life spheres, literature review
Correspondence Address: Kabanoff, B.; Flinders U of South Australia, , Bedford Park

Title: Primary process thinking and creativity
Affiliations: State U New York, Buffalo, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suler, J.R., State U New York, Buffalo, United States
Abstract: Hypothesizes that the creative act is a special form of interaction between primary and secondary process thinking in which a novel idea or insight is generated by the loose, illogical, and highly subjective ideation of primary process. It is then molded by secondary process into a context that is socially appropriate and meaningful to others. Although research evidence demonstrating that creativity is determined by the amount of primary process participation is weak, the evidence does reveal how creative ability is related to the extent to which secondary process initiates an integrative control over primary process manifestations. The distinction between scientific and artistic creativity is discussed. Also discussed is how some creative styles may rely on the direct access of secondary process to primary process thinking, whereas other styles may involve the use of special secondary process functions derived from primary process in the course of development. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: historical & empirical review of creativity as interaction of primary & secondary process thinking
Correspondence Address: Suler, J.R.; State U New York, Buffalo, United States

Authors: Zuckerman M., Buchsbaum M.S., Murphy D.L.
Title: Sensation seeking and its biological correlates
Authors with affiliations: Zuckerman, M., U Delaware, Newark, United States; Buchsbaum, M.S.; Murphy, D.L.
Abstract: Reviews the trait of sensation seeking and the biological phenomena associated with it: strength of the initial orienting reflex, augmenting vs reducing of the average evoked potential, MAO, and gonadal hormones (both androgen and estrogens). Both psychological and biological measures have retest reliabilities that are characteristic of stable traits. Twin studies show moderate to strong genetic control of the personality and of several biological measures. Several behavioral characteristics that are associated with the trait in humans are also related to the biological traits in animals, including sociability and social dominance, reactivity to novel situations, and play. In humans, sexual experience, interest in new situations, experiences with drugs, manic-depressive tendencies, and psychopathy are associated with both sensation seeking and its biological correlates. Age and sex differences show some parallels and some differences between sensation seeking and its biological correlates. (6 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: psychological & biological & genetic aspects of sensation seeking trait, research review
Correspondence Address: Zuckerman, M.; U Delaware, Newark, United States

Title: The role of team development in organizational effectiveness: A critical review
Affiliations: Texas A and M U, Coll of Business Administration
Authors with affiliations: Woodman, R.W., Texas A and M U, Coll of Business Administration; Sherwood, J.J.
Abstract: Describes the technology of team development, as distinguished from T-group or sensitivity training. Although there is general support in empirical literature for the finding that team building elicits positive affective responses from participants, the linkage between team building and improved work group performance remains largely unsubstantiated. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: team development vs T group training, organizational effectiveness, research review
Correspondence Address: Woodman, R.W.; Texas A and M U,

Title: Likelihood ratio tests of hypotheses: Comments on Pitz's article and some alternative procedures
Authors with affiliations: Marler, M.R., U Missouri, Colombia
Abstract: G. F. Pitz (see record 1979-22690-001) has recommended the use of likelihood ratio tests to decide between alternative subjective probability distributions on the parameters of a distribution that describes observations. A few criticisms of this recommendation are presented, and an alternative is described (i.e., the likelihood ratio, based on the sampling distribution of a test statistic, given the alternative hypothetical values of the parameter). (8 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: likelihood ratio tests of hypotheses, criticism of G. F. Pitz's
Correspondence Address: Marler, M.R.; U MissouriColombia

Title: Using likelihood ratios to test imprecise hypotheses
Affiliations: Southern Illinois U, Carbondale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pitz, G.F., Southern Illinois U, Carbondale, United States
Abstract: Responds to the suggestion by M. R. Marler (see record 1980-22531-001) that likelihood ratio tests should be based on precise hypotheses rather than on the imprecise hypotheses recommended by G. F. Pitz (see record 1979-22690-001). Precise hypotheses, however, are usually false and hence are rarely worth testing. In any case, the correct procedure for testing precise hypotheses is not that suggested by Marler, but a special case of the procedure described by Pitz. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: likelihood ratio tests of hypotheses, reply to criticism of M. R. Marler
Correspondence Address: Pitz, G.F.; Southern Illinois U, Carbondale, United States

Title: Measurement scales and statistics: Resurgence of an old misconception
Authors with affiliations: Gaito, J., York U, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: S. S. Stevens (1946) stated that there is a relationship between psychological measurement scales and statistical procedures such that parametric techniques require the presence of at least interval scale data. This idea was incorporated into numerous statistics books, but has been attacked and shown to be fallacious. This problem is reviewed, and measurement scales and statistical aspects are considered. The misconception was previously and is presently based on a confusion between measurement theory and statistical theory. For statistical tests of null hypothesis, "the numbers do not know where they came from." (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: psychological measurement scales & statistical procedures, criticism of S. S. Stevens's misconception
Correspondence Address: Gaito, J.; York U, Toronto, Canada

Title: Additive constants model: A randomized response technique for eliminating evasiveness to quantitative response questions
Authors with affiliations: Himmelfarb, S., U Louisville; Edgell, S.E.
Abstract: The randomized response technique (RRT) was designed to eliminate distortions of answers and refusals to respond to questions of a sensitive nature. A general additive constants RRT model is presented for application to questions that require a numerical response. Three special cases of the additive constants model are described and shown to be more statistically efficient than the most efficient, but idealized case of the unrelated question quantitative response model RRT. A few suggestions for implementing the additive constants model are given and discussed. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: additive constants randomized response technique model, elimination of evasiveness to quantitative response questions
Correspondence Address: Himmelfarb, S.

Title: Inbreeding depression and IQ
Authors with affiliations: Kamin, L.J., Princeton U
Abstract: To some authorities, studies of inbreeding depression and IQ represent "unassailable" or "impressive" evidence for the heritability of IQ; to other authorities, the same evidence is "meager and ambiguous." To study this discrepancy, a detailed review is made of 6 studies of the children of cousin marriages and 3 studies of the children of incestuous matings. These studies, taken as a whole, provide no substantial evidence for an inbreeding depression effect within the polygenic system that is commonly asserted to determine IQ. (24 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: inbreeding depression of IQ, literature review
Index Keywords: article; child; consanguinity; homozygote; human; intelligence; Child; Consanguinity; Homozygote; Human; Intelligence
Correspondence Address: Kamin, L.J.

Title: Economic change as a cause of behavioral disorder
Affiliations: U California, Public Policy Research Organization, Irvine
Authors with affiliations: Dooley, D., U California, Public Policy Research Organization, Irvine; Catalano, R.
Abstract: Classifies the literature concerned with the relationship of economic variables to behavioral disorder into 4 methodological categories by 2 orthogonal dimensions: cross-sectional vs longitudinal and individual aggregate. Because of their promise for determining the causal sequence of economic and disorder variables, longitudinal studies are assembled and reviewed. To coordinate research in this area, a model is offered that synthesizes many of the theoretical links joining economic change and behavioral disorder. This model's utility is illustrated with an overview of its implications for interventions at various levels. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: economic change, behavior disorders, literature review
Index Keywords: article; human; mental disease; psychological aspect; socioeconomics; Human; Mental Disorders; Socioeconomic Factors; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.
Correspondence Address: Dooley, D.; U California, , Irvine

Title: Statistical versus traditional procedures for summarizing research findings
Affiliations: U Missouri, Ctr for Research in Social Behavior, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, H.M., U Missouri, Ctr for Research in Social Behavior, Colombia; Rosenthal, R.
Abstract: Studied whether the conclusions drawn after using traditional or statistical combining procedures differed from one another. 32 graduate students and 9 faculty members were randomly assigned to use 1 of the 2 techniques to draw inferences about an identical set of related studies. It was found that users of the statistical method perceived more support present in the literature and estimated a larger magnitude of effect than did traditional reviewers. Conditions did not differ with regard to recommendations for future research. Although several differences were uncovered that were related to academic status, combining procedure effects were general across academic status and reviewer gender. The desirability of adopting statistical procedures in psychology is discussed. (13 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: statistical vs traditional procedures, summarization of psychology research findings, college students & faculty
Index Keywords: article; female; human; male; research; social behavior; Female; Human; Male; Research; Social Behavior; Statistics; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.
Correspondence Address: Cooper, H.M.; U Missouri, Colombia

Title: Psychological factors and hypertension: A status report
Authors with affiliations: Harrell, J.P., Virginia State U
Abstract: Five research paradigms are evaluated for their impact on the psychosomatic approach to hypertension. Recent findings indicate that there are a number of physiological similarities between borderline hypertension and the blood pressure changes that occur during laboratory stress. Behavioral factors may play a role in established hypertension through their impact on baroreceptor activity, blood volume adjustments, or sodium retention. In general, attempts to link hypertension with environmental events and personality have not added greatly to knowledge about hypertension. However, findings suggest that the Type A coronary-prone behavior pattern is related to blood pressure levels, and there is some evidence that personality variables may be related to blood pressure levels in certain physiological subtypes of essential hypertensives. It is proposed that psychological factors in hypertension will be most profitably studied when individual differences in both physiological and psychological dimensions are assessed in conjunction with the manipulations of laboratory stressors. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: research paradigms, psychosomatic aspects of hypertension, literature review
Index Keywords: animal; article; blood pressure; human; hypertension; hypothalamus; mental stress; personality; physiology; pressoreceptor; psychological aspect; Animal; Blood Pressure; Human; Hypertension; Hypothalamus; Personality; Pressoreceptors; Stress, Psychological; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.
Correspondence Address: Harrell, J.P.

Title: Conversion reaction: Anachronism or evolutionary form? A review of the neurologic, behavioral, and psychoanalytic literature?
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.M.
Abstract: Surveys the literature on conversion reactions (CRs) such as hypoesthesia or anesthesia, which have appeared in contemporary society. The dynamics are considered from neurophysiologic, behavioristic, and psychoanalytic points of view. The relationship of CRs to hysterical neuroses and the hysterical personality types and the boundaries for inclusion of symptoms are established. Neurologic formulations explore the role of inhibition at an operational level and the correlation between organic brain disease and CR disorders; behavioristic and social learning theories deal with the effect of environmental stimulation on CR symptoms; and psychoanalytically oriented theory deals with repression, intrapsychic conflict, condensation, and displacement in producing CRs. Psychological testing decreases the dependence on symptomatic diagnoses, providing information about the cognitive and affective styles that underlie physical or behavioral symptoms. (87 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: neurologic & behavioral & psychoanalytic aspects, conversion reactions, literature review
Index Keywords: article; conversion disorder; human; hypesthesia; hysteria; mental stress; psychoanalytic theory; psychological aspect; social environment; Conversion Disorder; Human; Hypesthesia; Hysteria; Psychoanalytic Theory; Social Environment; Stress, Psychological

Title: Reading disability and lateral asymmetry: An information-processing analysis
Affiliations: U California Inst of Human Learning, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Naylor, H., U California Inst of Human Learning, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Reviews research claiming to support the view that reading disability results from a disorder of cerebral asymmetry, analyzing it from an information-processing perspective. The studies involved complex tasks on which reading-disabled children invariably performed poorly. However, the tasks comprise multiple processing stages, each of which may or may not be lateralized. It is concluded that there is little experimental basis for the disorder of cerebral asymmetry hypothesis in these studies, due to lack of consideration for the processing stages at which the children may be failing. (78 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: information processing & effect of cerebral asymmetry on reading disability, literature review
Index Keywords: article; child; dyslexia; hearing; hemispheric dominance; human; psychological aspect; short term memory; touch; vision; Auditory Perception; Child; Dominance, Cerebral; Dyslexia; Human; Memory, Short-Term; Touch; Visual Perception
Correspondence Address: Naylor, H.; U California Inst of Human Learning, Berkeley, United States

Title: Biased assessment of program impact due to psychometric artifacts
Affiliations: Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bejar, I.I., Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States
Abstract: Examines the implications of comparing treatment groups on a test that is not psychometrically invariant. Some situations under which lack of invariance may arise are discussed. The implications for evaluation research are investigated under a variety of circumstances, including the individual level at several points in time (i.e., growth studies), pre-posttest designs, pretest-only designs, pre-posttest 1-group designs, and mastery testing. It is concluded that lack of invariance of the measurement instrument is a constant threat in evaluation research. Since invariance is well-defined only within item characteristic curve theory, it is recommended that it be adopted as the psychometric backbone of evaluation research. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: lack of test invariance, evaluation research & assessment of social & educational program impact
Correspondence Address: Bejar, I.I.; Educational Testing Service, Princeton, NJ, United States

Title: Evaluating causal models: An application of maximum-likelihood analysis of structural equations
Authors with affiliations: Maruyama, G., U Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; McGarvey, B.
Abstract: Describes how causal modeling techniques can be improved through the use of maximum-likelihood analysis of structural equations. Within the context of scholastic achievement, the logic of applying this approach to causal modeling studies is presented, and the advantages of such an approach are elaborated. As a demonstration, a computer program called Linear Structural Relations, appropriate for causal modeling techniques, is used to analyze data that explore hypothesized causal relations between peer acceptance and classroom achievement. (28 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: maximum likelihood analysis of structural equations, evaluation of causal models
Correspondence Address: Maruyama, G.; U Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States

Authors: Keselman H.J., Rogan J.C., Mendoza J.L., Breen L.J.
Title: Testing the validity conditions of repeated measures F tests
Authors with affiliations: Keselman, H.J., U Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada; Rogan, J.C.; Mendoza, J.L.; Breen, L.J.
Abstract: H. Huynh et al (see record 1979-32716-001) found that J. W. Mauchly's (1940) W test, which can be used by itself or in conjunction with G. E. P. Box's (1954) modified M test to assess the validity of conventional repeated measures F tests, is robust to forms of nonnormality that they maintained typify many types of psychological data. Consequently, they suggested using the W test as a preliminary test. Data are presented to demonstrate the futility of attempting to assess the validity conditions. The 3-stage procedure of S. W. Greenhouse et al (see record 1960-03639-001) is recommended as an efficient univariate testing procedure for assessing the effects of repeated measures. (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: testing validity conditions of repeated measures F test
Correspondence Address: Keselman, H.J.; U Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada

Authors: Crosby F., Bromley S., Saxe L.
Title: Recent unobtrusive studies of Black and White discrimination and prejudice: A literature review
Authors with affiliations: Crosby, F., Yale U; Bromley, S.; Saxe, L.
Abstract: Reviews recent unobtrusive studies of anti-Black racism among White Americans. It focuses on experiments on helping behavior, aggression, and nonverbal communication. In each of these areas, data suggest that anti-Black sentiments are much more prevalent among Whites than the survey data lead one to expect. An attempt is made to reconcile the empirical findings with 3 models of social attitudes and behavior. The pattern of results accords well with the models of H. C. Kelman (see record 1964-00831-001) and D. T. Campbell (1936), whereas the model proposed by A. Poskocil (see record 1978-00893-001) is found to be deficient. It is concluded that anti-Black prejudice is still strong among US Whites. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: prejudice against Blacks, helping behavior & aggression & nonverbal communication, literature review
Correspondence Address: Crosby, F.

Title: Psychology of rumor reconsidered
Authors with affiliations: Rosnow, R.L., Temple U
Abstract: The "basic law of rumor" of G. W. Allport and L. J. Postman (1947), which asserts that rumor strength varies with thematic importance and ambiguity, is called into question. As a possible synthesizing proposition, it is instead postulated that rumor results from combinations of uncertainty and anxiety that are related to rumor strength differently as state and trait factors. (100 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: theory & psychology of rumor, criticism of G. W. Allport & L. J. Postman's theory
Correspondence Address: Rosnow, R.L.

Title: Estimation and testing of bivariate association using data generated by the randomized response technique
Authors with affiliations: Kraemer, H.C., Stanford U, Medical Ctr
Abstract: The randomized response technique is a method for decreasing the frequency of evasive or misleading responses to sensitive questions. Although generally used in univariate applications, it is not limited to such uses. A method is proposed for estimation of true-response correlations, not only for dichotomous response data but for nominal data with more than 2 responses and for normally distributed responses, when data are generated using a randomized response technique. (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimation of bivariate association using data generated by randomized response technique
Correspondence Address: Kraemer, H.C.

Authors: Holland T.R., Levi M., Watson C.G.
Title: Canonical correlation in the analysis of a contingency table
Authors with affiliations: Holland, T.R., California Inst for Men, Chino; Levi, M.; Watson, C.G.
Abstract: Illustrates the use of canonical correlation in the analysis of a contingency table with regard to the strength and statistical significance of the overall association between 2 sets of categories and also with respect to the number, magnitude, and composition of independent dimensions along which such sets are related to each other. It is argued that canonical correlation, although equivalent to chi-square in certain respects, provides considerably more information and is thus preferable in instances in which complex unidimensional or possible multidimensional associations exist between categorical variables. (8 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: canonical correlation in contingency table analysis
Correspondence Address: Holland, T.R.; California Inst for Men, Chino

Authors: Adams H.E., Feuerstein M., Fowler J.L.
Title: Migraine headache: Review of parameters, etiology, and intervention
Authors with affiliations: Adams, H.E., U Georgia; Feuerstein, M.; Fowler, J.L.
Abstract: Reviews research on various characteristics of migraine headaches, the factors contributing to their etiology, and treatment techniques. Emphasis is placed on psychological intervention. Theoretical issues involving biological and psychological factors in migraine etiology are discussed, and a psychobiological model for the migraine disorder is proposed. Areas requiring further basic and clinical research are identified. Major conclusions include the following: (a) etiological factors of migraine remain unclear. (b) Pharmacological intervention does not constitute an adequate treatment method in terms of headache elimination. (c) Although numerous psychological treatment approaches have been reported in the literature, there are few well-controlled evaluations, and definitive conclusions regarding differential effectiveness of the various techniques are difficult. (d) A biofeedback approach directed at modifying the peripheral pain mechanism in migraine appears to be a promising treatment technique. (21/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: etiology & treatment techniques, migraine headache, review of research
Index Keywords: adult; aged; article; behavior therapy; emotion; female; human; male; migraine; personality; psychological aspect; psychophysiology; Adult; Aged; Behavior Therapy; Biofeedback (Psychology); Emotions; Female; Human; Male; Middle Age; Migraine; Personality
Correspondence Address: Adams, H.E.

Title: Status of electroconvulsive therapy: Review of the outcome literature
Authors with affiliations: Scovern, A.W., U South Carolina, Colombia; Kilmann, P.R.
Abstract: Reviews 60 studies that compared the therapeutic efficacy of ECT with that of control procedures or alternative treatment modes and 30 studies that examined patient and treatment variables related to improvement. A methodological evaluation was conducted, focusing on 4 components of experimental design: patients, treatment, testing periods, and outcome measures. ECT appears to be an effective treatment for endogenous depression, particularly when the depression is severe or when it is accompanied by delusions. The fast action of ECT warrants its use when the depressed patient is at risk for suicide. Patients other than endogenous depressives, however, appear to be poor candidates for ECT. Standard diagnostic criteria are currently as accurate as various indices and rating scales in predicting the response of depressives to ECT. Unilateral electrode placement and brief-stimulus ECT are promising due to the lessened postshock disturbance. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: patient & treatment variables & therapeutic efficacy of ECS treatment, literature review
Index Keywords: article; bipolar disorder; depression; electroconvulsive therapy; human; schizophrenia; treatment outcome; Bipolar Disorder; Depression; Electroconvulsive Therapy; Human; Outcome and Process Assessment (Health Care); Schizophrenia

Title: Configuration and combination laws in conditioning with compound stimuli
Affiliations: U New South Wales, Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Kehoe, E.J., U New South Wales, Sydney, Australia; Gormezano, I.
Abstract: Reviews the animal learning literature on the combination laws for responding to a compound stimulus and its components. Attention is focused on responding to bisensory compound stimuli (e.g., light plus tone), as examined in conditioning, discrimination, and generalization procedures. The issue that is examined has been generated by configural and elementalist hypotheses regarding the effective stimuli that constitute a compound stimulus. As the data accumulate, the theories appear to be converging into a coherent representation of a compound stimulus as a functionally distinct stimulus that is, nevertheless, lawfully related to its components. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.

Correspondence Address: Kehoe, E.J.; U New South Wales, Sydney, Australia

Title: Parental death during childhood and adult depression: A critical review of the literature
Authors with affiliations: Crook, T., NIMH, Rockville, MD, United States; Eliot, J.
Abstract: Parental death during childhood is widely viewed as an event so traumatic that it produces not only immediate grief and despondency but also a predisposition to react with depression when faced with loss or rejection in adult life. Empirical evidence relating to the relationship between parental death and depression is provided by more than 20 controlled studies conducted during the past 2 decades. A critical review of these studies is presented, and it is concluded that parental death during childhood has not been established as a factor of etiologic significance in adult depression or any subtype of adult depression studied to date. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.

Authors: Braucht G.N., Loya F., Jamieson K.J.
Title: Victims of violent death: A critical review
Authors with affiliations: Braucht, G.N., U Denver; Loya, F.; Jamieson, K.J.
Abstract: Assesses the present state of knowledge regarding victims of suicide, accidental death, and homicide and the formal characteristics of the relevant empirical research models. Knowledge of these victims and their circumstances is fragmented because few investigators have studied more than one mode of violent death and because few studies have examined data at both the individual and environmental levels of analysis. The research models that have been used to study violent death are shown to have particular deficiencies in terms of their ability to reflect interactions between environmental and personal factors. A research model better suited to interactionist analyses is developed, and its usefulness for further research is discussed. (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: characteristics of empirical research models, assessment of knowledge regarding victims of suicide & accidental death & homicide, literature review
Index Keywords: accident; article; death; homicide; human; psychological aspect; suicide; violence; Accidents; Death; Homicide; Human; Suicide; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Violence

Title: Experimental research on third-party intervention in conflict: Toward some generalizations
Authors with affiliations: Rubin, J.Z., Tufts U
Abstract: Despite the importance of 3rd-party intervention in conflict, little experimental research has been conducted on the intervention process. Moreover, although this laboratory work is limited to a few dozen experiments, it contains many contradictory findings. The present article advances 3 explanatory strands, or generalizations, that wind through this experimental literature: (a) Third parties facilitate concession making without loss of face, thereby promoting more rapid and effective conflict resolutions than would otherwise occur. (b) Traditional 3rd-party intervention techniques that are effective when conflict intensity is relatively low may prove to be ineffectual and even exacerbating when conflict intensity is high. (c) The parties to a conflict may view 3rd-party intervention as an unwelcome and unwanted intrusion. To the extent that the disputants can resolve conflict of their own accord, they will. (50 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: role of 3rd party intervention in conflict, literature review
Index Keywords: article; conflict; family therapy; human; interpersonal communication; marital therapy; psychotherapy; Communication; Conflict (Psychology); Family Therapy; Human; Marital Therapy; Psychotherapy; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.

Title: Stressful life events and schizophrenia: A review of the research literature
Affiliations: New York State Psychiatric Inst, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rabkin, J.G., New York State Psychiatric Inst, NY, United States
Abstract: Assesses published studies of the frequency and nature of stressful life events reported by schizophrenic patients, diagnosed according to specified criteria, in comparison with those reported by members of control groups. Methodological problems that are particularly relevant to the study of life events and schizophrenia are also considered. Three study designs are identified: comparisons of schizophrenic with other psychiatric patients, of schizophrenics with normals, and of relapsed with nonrelapsed schizophrenics. No study found more events reported by schizophrenics than by other patient groups. Findings are inconsistent regarding event frequencies reported by schizophrenics and normals. More events were reported by relapsed than by nonrelapsed schizophrenics. Overall, the research evidence indicates a weaker relationship between life events and schizophrenia onset than the clinical literature suggests, although methodological limitations preclude firm conclusions at this time. (31 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: frequency & nature of stressful life events, schizophrenic patients, literature review
Index Keywords: article; human; life event; mental stress; psychological aspect; psychology; recurrent disease; Human; Life Change Events; Recurrence; Schizophrenic Psychology; Stress, Psychological
Correspondence Address: Rabkin, J.G.; New York State Psychiatric Inst, NY, United States

Title: Sex bias in counseling and psychotherapy
Affiliations: U Colorado, Lab of Educational Research, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, M.L., U Colorado, Lab of Educational Research, Boulder, United States
Abstract: A review of the literature suggests that the notion that existing research proves the sex bias inherent in counseling and psychotherapy is pervasive. Almost every subsequent study has taken as a major premise the finding by I. K. Broverman et al (see record 1970-06951-001) that clinicians hold different standards of mental health for men and women. In the present research, both the published and unpublished studies of sex bias in either counseling or psychotherapy were analyzed and their results integrated using meta-analytic techniques. Overall results show an absence of bias against women or against nonstereotyped roles for women in studies of either counselors or psychotherapists. In published studies there was a small sex-bias effect, and unpublished studies showed the same magnitude of bias toward women and a degree of rigor in research design at least as good as that evident in published studies. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sex bias in counseling & psychotherapy, literature review
Index Keywords: article; attitude; counseling; female; gender identity; human; human relation; identity; male; psychotherapy; Attitude of Health Personnel; Counseling; Female; Gender Identity; Human; Identification (Psychology); Male; Professional-Patient Relations; Psychotherapy
Correspondence Address: Smith, M.L.; U Colorado, , Boulder, United States

Title: Radical behaviorist epistemology
Authors with affiliations: Zuriff, G.E., Wheaton Coll
Abstract: In contrast with other varieties of behaviorism, radical behaviorism (RB) claims that it alone can deal with private events in science because it rejects the doctrine of "truth by agreement." However, several schools of behaviorism that are committed to an intersubjective agreement criterion of truth have nevertheless included private events in their theories. RB has also rejected truth criteria based on incorrigibility, either of immediate experience or of scientific observation. Instead, according to one interpretation, RB has adopted a version of the correspondence theory of truth, and, according to another preferred interpretation, RB has adopted a pragmatic theory of truth. However, various problems arise in applying these criteria. These problems may be resolved by interpreting the criterion of truth that is generated by a science of behavior as logically analogous to the set of ethical values that is generated by that science. (56 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: criteria of truth in radical behaviorism epistemology
Correspondence Address: Zuriff, G.E.; Wheaton Coll

Title: Factors that affect Type I and Type II error rates in the analysis of multidimensional contingency tables
Affiliations: Ohio State U, Faculty of Management Sciences, Columbus, United States
Authors with affiliations: Milligan, G.W., Ohio State U, Faculty of Management Sciences, Columbus, United States
Abstract: Techniques for the analysis of multidimensional contingency tables have recently been developed. Since the statistical procedures are fairly new, little is known about the operating characteristics of the hypothesis tests in terms of Type I and Type II error rates. The present report provides some basic information on the characteristics of the testing procedures with respect to 7 factors: effects of small sample size, power estimation, test nonorthogonality, alternative chi-square statistics, conditional chi-square tests, collapsing across categories, and collapsing across variables. Monte Carlo simulation results and asymptotic theory suggest that the hypothesis testing procedures based on the log-linear model do possess reasonable operating characteristics; however, care must be taken to ensure that the tests are applied and interpreted appropriately. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: factors affecting Type I & Type II error rates in analysis of multidimensional contingency tables
Correspondence Address: Milligan, G.W.; Ohio State U, , Columbus, United States

Title: Tests for comparing elements of a correlation matrix
Authors with affiliations: Steiger, J.H., U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: In psychological research, it is desirable to be able to make statistical comparisons between correlation coefficients measured on the same individuals. For example, an experimenter (E) may wish to assess whether 2 predictors correlate equally with a criterion variable. In another situation, the E may wish to test the hypothesis that an entire matrix of correlations has remained stable over time. The present article reviews the literature on such tests, points out some statistics that should be avoided, and presents a variety of techniques that can be used safely with medium to large samples. Several numerical examples are provided. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: tests for comparing elements of correlation matrix, literature review
Correspondence Address: Steiger, J.H.; U British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada

Title: Bayesian Analysis of Random Response Models
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pitz, G.F., Department of Psychology, Southern Illinois University, Carbondale, IL, United States
Abstract: Fidler and Kleinknecht described a method for eliciting more valid responses to sensitive questions that people might be reluctant to answer truthfully. Unfortunately, their method of analysis, which was based on maximum likelihood estimates, can give rise to estimates of a probability that are less than zero or greater than one. This problem can be avoided by using a Bayesian analysis of the model, which gives a more useful estimate when the response proportions are extreme or when the sample size is not large. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Bayesian analysis; random response models; sensitive questions; valid responses
Correspondence Address: Pitz, G.F.; Department of Psychology, , Carbondale, IL, United States

Title: Aspirations of the Future Editor: An Editorial
Affiliations: Princeton U, Princeton, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, G.A., Princeton U, Princeton, NJ, United States
Abstract: As the new editor for Psychological Bulletin George A. Miller discusses the history of the journal. He goes on to discuss where he wishes to take the content of the journal in the future. He would like to invite those expert in and enthusiastic about physiological psychology, neuropsychology, psychopharmacology, behavioral medicine, behavioral neurophysiology, cognitive neuroscience, and all the rapidly twigging branches of the brain sciences to contribute reviews--preferably well-written reviews that a general psychologist, with a little work, could understand. Miller is distressed by a vision of psychophysiology gradually drifting away from psychology, to the detriment of both. If an editor can help to reverse this trend, he stands ready to try. He would also like to see more articles that appeal to a broad variety of readers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: brain sciences; Psychological Bulletin; psychology; psychophysiology
Correspondence Address: Miller, G.A.; Princeton U, Princeton, NJ, United States

Title: Performance rating
Authors with affiliations: Landy, F.J., Pennsylvania State U, University Park; Farr, J.L.
Abstract: The most ubiquitous method of performance appraisal is rating. Ratings, however, have been shown to be prone to various types of systematic and random error. Studies relating to performance rating are reviewed under the following headings: roles, context, vehicle, process, and results. In general, cognitive characteristics of raters seem to hold the most promise for increased understanding of the rating process. A process model of performance rating is derived from the literature. Research in the areas of implicit personality theory and variance partitioning is combined with the process model to suggest a unified approach to understanding performance judgments in applied settings. (6 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: roles & conflict & vehicle & process & results, performance ratings, literature review
Correspondence Address: Landy, F.J.; Pennsylvania State U, University Park

Title: Note on an especially simple partitioning of chi-square from questionnaires
Affiliations: U Waterloo, Faculty of Mathematics, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Barnard, G.A., U Waterloo, Faculty of Mathematics, Canada
Abstract: Demonstrates how the chi-square test of association may be partitioned into 2 nearly orthogonal components that are useful in questionnaire item analysis: one that corresponds to difference in attitudes between groups and one that corresponds to difference in strengths of attitudes between groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: partitioning chi-square test of association, questionnaire item analysis
Correspondence Address: Barnard, G.A.; U Waterloo, Canada

Title: Measuring clustering in free recall
Affiliations: U California, Graduate School of Education, Santa Barbara, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hubert, L.J., U California, Graduate School of Education, Santa Barbara, United States; Levin, J.R.
Abstract: Introduces a measure theta as a general index of clustering in free recall. The theta statistic, based on k-place functions that are defined on 2-item sequences, may be used to evaluate either categorical clustering or subjective organization. By varying the k-place functions, the measure theta can be shown to accommodate J. W. Pellegrino's (1971) work on subjective organization and L. J. Hubert and J. R. Levin's (1977) categorical clustering paradigm. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: theta statistic, measurement of clustering in free recall
Correspondence Address: Hubert, L.J.; U California, , Santa Barbara, United States

Title: Empirical validation of psychological constructs: A secondary analysis
Authors with affiliations: Rezmovic, E.L., Northwestern U; Rezmovic, V.
Abstract: Examined similarity in the underlying structures of 12 needs (H. A. Murray, 1938) as measured by the Personality Research Form and peer ratings. Exploratory factor analysis indicated that 6 factors could account for the 12 traits satisfactorily. However, an invariant factor pattern common to the 2 methods could not be found. Results indicate that the underlying structures of the 2 methods are not the same, despite earlier findings (G. J. Huba and S. L. Hamilton, 1976) to the contrary. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Personality Research Form vs peer ratings, analysis of underlying structures of needs
Correspondence Address: Rezmovic, E.L.

Title: Childhood depression: Three basic but questionable assumptions in the Lefkowitz and Burton critique
Authors with affiliations: Costello, C.G., U Calgary, Canada
Abstract: Discusses 3 questionable assumptions in the M. M. Lefkowitz and N. Burton (1978) critique of the concept of childhood depression: (a) If the behaviors thought to constitute the syndrome of depression are prevalent in normal children, they cannot be considered pathological; therefore the syndrome does not exist. (b) If the behaviors thought to constitute the syndrome of depression are found to disappear as a function of time, they cannot be considered pathological. (c) Problems that remit spontaneously do not need clinical intervention. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: childhood depression, criticism of M. M. Lefkowitz & N. Burton's critique
Index Keywords: article; child; depression; differential diagnosis; human; preschool child; psychological aspect; Child; Child, Preschool; Depression; Diagnosis, Differential; Human
Correspondence Address: Costello, C.G.; U CalgaryCanada

Authors: Hobbs S.A., Moguin L.E., Tyroler M., Lahey B.B.
Title: Cognitive behavior therapy with children: Has clinical utility been demonstrated?
Authors with affiliations: Hobbs, S.A., U Tulsa; Moguin, L.E.; Tyroler, M.; Lahey, B.B.
Abstract: Considerable attention has recently been focused on intervention techniques designed to alter cognitive processes in an attempt to modify clinically relevant child behaviors. Studies in which children have been taught cognitive mediating strategies (methods collectively known as cognitive behavior therapy) are evaluated in terms of S populations, adequacy of outcome measures, experimental and statistical methodology, and consistency of findings. In general, deficiencies are found on all dimensions. Although some studies have reported promising results that merit further investigation, methodological improvements are necessary before the clinical utility of cognitive behavior therapy with children can be documented. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: cognitive behavior therapy, change in cognitive processes & behavior, children, literature review
Index Keywords: article; behavior disorder; behavior therapy; child; cognition; human; hyperkinesia; impulsiveness; methodology; Behavior Therapy; Child; Child Behavior Disorders; Cognition; Human; Hyperkinesis; Impulsive Behavior
Correspondence Address: Hobbs, S.A.

Title: Childhood depression: A reply to Costello
Affiliations: New York State Dept of Mental Hygiene, Bureau of Special Projects Research, Albany
Authors with affiliations: Lefkowitz, M.M., New York State Dept of Mental Hygiene, Bureau of Special Projects Research, Albany
Abstract: The present author defends his earlier article (M. M. Lefkowitz and N. Burton, 1978) against the criticisms made by G. G. Costello. It is argued that what Costello terms "questionable assumptions" are actually a measurement operation, a fact, and an axiom. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: childhood depression, reply to criticism of C. G. Costello
Index Keywords: article; child; depression; differential diagnosis; human; preschool child; psychological aspect; Child; Child, Preschool; Depression; Diagnosis, Differential; Human
Correspondence Address: Lefkowitz, M.M.; New York State Dept of Mental Hygiene, , Albany

Title: Psychosocial correlates of breast cancer and its treatments
Affiliations: U Southern California, Psychological Research, Service Ctr
Authors with affiliations: Meyerowitz, B.E., U Southern California, Psychological Research, Service Ctr
Abstract: Notes that in recent years, an interest in the quality of life of breast cancer patients has begun to emerge. With this increasing concern, psychologists and other mental health experts are being called on to consult with patients and medical personnel on the development of treatment and research programs. An evaluative review of the literature is presented that describes psychosocial correlates of breast cancer and its treatments. The literature has been divided into 2 sections: (a) the psychosocial impact of breast cancer and mastectomy and (b) the variables that influence the intensity and duration of that impact. (41/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: psychosocial correlates, breast cancer & treatment, literature review
Index Keywords: article; breast tumor; denial; female; human; mastectomy; mental stress; psychological aspect; quality of life; social adaptation; social environment; Breast Neoplasms; Denial (Psychology); Female; Human; Mastectomy; Quality of Life; Social Adjustment; Social Environment; Stress, Psychological
Correspondence Address: Meyerowitz, B.E.; U Southern California,

Title: Fetal alcohol syndrome: Behavioral teratology
Affiliations: Research Inst on Alcoholism, Buffalo, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abel, E.L., Research Inst on Alcoholism, Buffalo, NY, United States
Abstract: The fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is a pattern of physical malformations observed in the offspring of women who drink alcohol during pregnancy. The most serious effect of in utero exposure to alcohol is mental retardation. Although the physical characteristics associated with the FAS have been attributed to the direct effects of alcohol, conditions secondary to alcohol intake (e.g., altered nutrition) cannot be eliminated as etiological factors in the impairment in cognitive function. Although animal models have been developed to study the question of direct vs indirect causation, there is little agreement in the results of these studies, and the methodology used leaves much to be desired in terms of adequate controls. (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy & related conditions, fetal alcohol syndrome, review of human & animal literature
Index Keywords: neurotransmitter; aggression; animal; animal behavior; brain; drinking behavior; drug effect; emotion; female; fetal alcohol syndrome; human; iatrogenic disease; mental deficiency; metabolism; newborn; pregnancy; psychological aspect; rat; recall; review; Aggression; Alcohol Drinking; Animal; Behavior, Animal; Brain; Emotions; Female; Fetal Alcohol Syndrome; Human; Infant, Newborn; Mental Recall; Mental Retardation; Neurotransmitters; Pregnancy; Rats

Title: Power of chi-square tests for 2 × 2 contingency tables with small expected frequencies
Affiliations: U Texas School of Medicine, Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Overall, J.E., U Texas School of Medicine, Houston, United States
Abstract: Small expected frequencies in 2 × 2 contingency tables often occur because 1 of the categorical variables involves a relatively rare event. Formulas are presented for estimating the number of relatively rare events required to provide adequate power for chi-square tests. It is demonstrated that the power of chi-square tests of relationship in a 2 × 2 table with small expected frequencies in 1 row or column is so low that the tests are rendered essentially useless. The total numbers of relatively rare events that must be observed to provide adequate power against important differences in the binary response probabilities in 2 treatment groups are presented in tabular form. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: number of relatively rare events, adequate power for chi-square tests
Correspondence Address: Overall, J.E.; U Texas School of Medicine, Houston, United States

Title: Nonorthogonal analysis of variance--once again
Affiliations: U North Carolina, L. L. Thurstone Psychometric Lab, Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cramer, E.M., U North Carolina, L. L. Thurstone Psychometric Lab, Chapel Hill, United States; Appelbaum, M.I.
Abstract: In a previous article, the authors discussed the relationship between orthogonal and nonorthogonal ANOVA, noting that the problems traditionally associated with the nonorthogonal ANOVA are easily resolved by viewing ANOVA as a series of model comparisons. J. E. Overall et al described another method that they argued estimates the same parameters and tests the same hypotheses in both the orthogonal and nonorthogonal cases. In the current article it is noted that since this is true of all the methods under consideration, in the context of comparing linear models, a preference must be based on other grounds. In particular, it is shown that the authors' method is more powerful when there is no interaction or when there are small interaction effects. For the interactive case it is noted that the test of Overall et al is a test of equally weighted marginal means and that although marginal means may be of interest in some circumstances, the weights may be freely chosen, depending on the substantive problem. Any tests of significance in the interactive case are dependent on the weights used. (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: orthogonal vs nonorthogonal analysis of variance
Correspondence Address: Cramer, E.M.; U North Carolina, , Chapel Hill, United States

Title: Analysis of variance and the "second discipline" of scientific psychology: A historical account
Affiliations: American Hosp Supply Corp, Evanston, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rucci, A.J., American Hosp Supply Corp, Evanston, IL, United States; Tweney, R.D.
Abstract: Conducted a historical analysis of the period from 1925 to 1950 to investigate the incorporation of ANOVA techniques in psychological research. In addition to attempts to identify the earliest uses of ANOVA in psychology, the gradual incorporation of the technique was examined by counting its appearance in 6,457 articles appearing in major American psychological journals from 1935 through 1952. Expository articles and texts directed at psychologists were also identified, and a questionnaire survey of graduate psychology programs was conducted to establish how psychologists were introduced to ANOVA. Finally, the phylogeny of major contributors to American psychological statistics was established for the period. Data suggest a segmentation into 3 historical periods: (a) an initial, expository phase lasting until the onset of World War II; (b) a wartime interregnum during which use of ANOVA declined; and (c) a postwar resurgence, characterized by the institutionalization of ANOVA training. Although ANOVA had a major impact on experimental psychology, the data do not permit the conclusion that the incorporation of ANOVA in psychology in itself constituted a revolutionary "paradigm shift." (31/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: historical analysis of incorporation of analysis of variance techniques in psychological research, literature review
Correspondence Address: Rucci, A.J.; American Hosp Supply Corp, Evanston, IL, United States

Title: Note on the estimation of the squared cross-validated multiple correlation of a regression model
Authors with affiliations: Cattin, P., U Connecticut, Storrs, United States
Abstract: In a recent article, W. W. Rozeboom showed that there are estimators of the squared population cross-validated multiple correlation that are less biased that the estimators compared by N. Schmidt et al (1977). A simple version of a formula included in Rozeboom's study is shown to produce even less biased estimates. These formulas are a function of the squared population multiple correlation typically estimated with R. J. Wherry's (1931) formula. The bias of the estimates obtained with this formula is not negligible with small sample sizes, in which case a less biased estimator should be used. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimation of squared cross-validation multiple correlation of regression model
Correspondence Address: Cattin, P.; U Connecticut, Storrs, United States

Title: Job families: A review and discussion of their implications for personnel selection
Affiliations: US Office of Personnel Management, Personnel Research, Development Ctr, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pearlman, K., US Office of Personnel Management, Personnel Research, Development Ctr, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: Reviews the personnel literature on the development of job families and discusses the implications for personnel selection. Job family development is viewed as essentially a matter of behavior classification in the world of work. Accordingly, the review focuses on the basic taxonomic issues of objective, content, and method in job family construction. The discussion section explores the implications for several related objectives in personnel selection, all of which reflect different aspects of the broader objective of generalizing selection procedure validity. It is concluded that the approaches to developing job families that emphasize either the human attribute requirements or broad content structure of jobs are likely to prove more useful for both theory development and practical application in personnel selection than are approaches based on more molecular analyses of jobs. (4 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: development of job families, implications for personnel selection, literature review
Correspondence Address: Pearlman, K.; US Office of Personnel Management, , Washington, DC, United States

Title: Application of prediction analysis to developmental priority
Affiliations: U California, Graduate School of Education, Santa Barbara, United States
Authors with affiliations: Froman, T., U California, Graduate School of Education, Santa Barbara, United States; Hubert, L.J.
Abstract: Discusses the prediction analysis system introduced by D. Hildebrand et al (1977) as a method for statistically evaluating a hypothesized developmental priority between 2 variables. An alternative strategy of ordinal analysis, proposed by C. J. Brainerd and S. Brainerd (1972) and by C. J. Brainerd and M. Fraser (1975), is briefly reviewed and shown to be incorrect. The procedures advocated by Hildebrand et al are illustrated with examples based on J. F. Wohlwill's (1973) paradigm of developmental progression and on D. Moshman's (1977) work on J. H. Flavell and J. H. Wohlwill's (1969) 4-phase model of stage formation. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: prediction analysis system, statistical evaluation of hypothesized developmental priority between 2 variables
Correspondence Address: Froman, T.; U California, , Santa Barbara, United States

Authors: McCauley C., Stitt C.L., Segal M.
Title: Stereotyping: From prejudice to prediction
Authors with affiliations: McCauley, C., Bryn Mawr Coll; Stitt, C.L.; Segal, M.
Abstract: A brief review of stereotype research indicates that little has been discovered about stereotypes that are defined as bad generalizations and measured with the D. Katz and K. W. Braly (1933) checklist. C. McCauley and C. L. Stitt (1978) have proposed that stereotypes can be better understood as probabilistic predictions that distinguish one group from another. The practicality of the proposed diagnostic-ratio measure of stereotyping is argued, and the relation of the new measure to the Katz and Braly measure is discussed. W. Lippmann's (1922) arguments against stereotypes--that they are illogical in origin, resistant to new information, and obviously invalid--are shown to be inapplicable to probabilistic stereotypes. Other common arguments against stereotypes--their ethnocentrism, genetic implications, projected hostility, and exaggeration of real group differences--are shown to be arguments against particular stereotypes rather than arguments against stereotyping. Recent research indicating various cognitive biases in the formation and use of stereotypes is reviewed, and it is suggested that what is wrong with stereotyping is no more and no less than what is wrong with human conceptual behavior generally. (35 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1980 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stereotype research, literature review
Correspondence Address: McCauley, C.; Bryn Mawr Coll

Title: Index of literature reviews and summaries in the Psychological Bulletin, 1967-1978
Affiliations: American Psychological Assn, Educational Affairs Office, Washington, DC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benjamin, L.T., American Psychological Assn, Educational Affairs Office, Washington, DC, United States; Shaffer, L.S., American Psychological Assn, Educational Affairs Office, Washington, DC, United States
Abstract: Updates a previous compilation by T. Andrews and F. Kerr (1967) covering 1940-1966. Like the earlier index, the current one includes all articles that were wholly or largely reviews of a specialized area of literature, along with published comments on those review articles. Author and subject indexes are included. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1979 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: index of literature reviews & summaries in "Psychological Bulletin," 1967-78
Correspondence Address: Benjamin, L.T.; American Psychological Assn, , Washington, DC, United States

Title: Index of reviews and notes on statistical methods and research design in the Psychological Bulletin, 1967-1978
Authors with affiliations: Shaffer, L.S.; Benjamin, L.T.
Abstract: Updates the previous index of reviews and notes on statistical methods and research design compiled by T. Andrews (1967). Organization of this index is identical to that of the authors' index of literature reviews (see record 1980-06186-001), and summaries and articles on topics of statistics and research design that are included in the larger index are also included in this index. Author and subject indexes are included. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1979 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: index of reviews & notes on statistical methods & research design in "Psychological Bulletin", 1967-78
Correspondence Address: Shaffer, L.S., Nebraska Wesleyan U, United States

Authors: Bradley D.R., Bradley T.D., McGrath S.G., Cutcomb S.D.
Title: Type I error rate of the chi-square test in independence in R × C tables that have small expected frequencies
Authors with affiliations: Bradley, D.R., Bates Coll; Bradley, T.D.; McGrath, S.G.; Cutcomb, S.D.
Abstract: Sampling experiments are reported that show that the uncorrected chi-square test of independence is exceptionally robust with respect to small expected frequencies in R × C contingency tables. In general, error rates that exceed .06 occurred only when both marginal probability distributions were extremely skewed and sample size was small. Nevertheless, the quality of the approximation of chi-square probabilities for exact multinomial probabilities was sometimes poor, although excessive errors in approximation by W. G. Cochran's (1952) criteria usually resulted from actual error rates being smaller, not larger, than the nominal level. A distinction is made between accuracy of approximation and control of the Type I error rate as considerations dictating the advisability of using an approximate test. (38 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1979 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: robustness of chi-square test of independence
Correspondence Address: Bradley, D.R.; Bates Coll

Title: The construct validity of egocentrism
Affiliations: U Minnesota, Inst of Child Development, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ford, M.E., U Minnesota, Inst of Child Development, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: Briefly explains construct validation and applies it to egocentrism. Conceptual and operational referents of this construct are organized into 3 categories: visual/spatial egocentrism (what does the other see), affective egocentrism (what does the other feel), and cognitive/communicative egocentrism (what is the other thinking). Several kinds of reliability information are reported, and construct validity is evaluated primarily by examination of the relationships among measures of egocentrism within and between categories. Although interrater reliability and interrater agreement were found to be uniformly high for all egocentrism measures examined in a review, and the measurement reliability was usually adequate, a few tasks were not internally consistent. Overall, the construct validity of egocentrism was not supported, since most task intercorrelations were low and often nonsignificant. An alternative interpretation of the data based on cognitive constructs and task- and response-specific variables is proposed. (21/2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1979 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: egocentrism, construct validity
Correspondence Address: Ford, M.E.; U Minnesota, , Minneapolis, United States

Authors: O'Keefe J., Nadel L., Willner J.
Title: Tuning out irrelevancy? Comments on Solomon's temporal mapping view of the hippocampus
Affiliations: U London University Coll, Cerebral Functions Group, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: O'Keefe, J., U London University Coll, Cerebral Functions Group, England, United Kingdom; Nadel, L.; Willner, J.
Abstract: In his analysis of the present author's series of studies on the role of the hippocampus in spatial information processing (A. H. Black, L. Nadel, and J. O'Keefe; 1974, 1975, 1976, 1979), P. R. Solomon (see record 1980-04864-001) proposed an extension to the cognitive map theory of hippocampal function. He cites evidence drawn mainly from the literature on the classical conditioning of the rabbit's nictitating membrane response, which he claims can not be satisfactorily explained within the framework of the present theory. The present article shows that the deficits following hippocampal lesions can be predicted from understanding the role of place learning in each paradigm and shows that electrophysiological data are open to different interpretation. It is concluded that the data cited by Solomon do not require any modification of the theory. (2 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: hippocampal processing of spatial information, reply to criticism of P. R. Solomon's article
Index Keywords: animal; article; conditioned reflex; depth perception; hippocampus; orientation; physiology; rabbit; time perception; Animal; Conditioning, Classical; Hippocampus; Orientation; Rabbits; Space Perception; Time Perception
Correspondence Address: O'Keefe, J.; U London University Coll, , England, United Kingdom

Title: Temporal versus spatial information processing theories of hippocampal function
Authors with affiliations: Solomon, P.R., Williams Coll, Bronfman Science Ctr
Abstract: Several articles by A. H. Black, L. Nadel, J. O'Keefe, and their co-workers (1974, 1975, 1976, 1979) propose that the primary function of the hippocampus is to process spatial information. Although the spatial information processing view of hippocampal function accounts for much of the available data, it cannot account for the data from the classically conditioned rabbit nictitating membrane response preparation. The present article reviews these data and suggests that the hippocampus is involved in the processing of temporal as well as spatial information. (46 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: hippocampal processing of spatial vs temporal information, criticism of article by A. H. Black & L. Nadel & J. O'Keefe et al
