Title: The bogus pipeline: A new paradigm for measuring affect and attitude
Authors with affiliations: Jones, E.E., Duke U; Sigall, H.
Abstract: Considers that, if ss can be convinced that a physiological monitoring device is able to measure both the amplitude and direction of emotional response, their subsequent attempts to predict what the machine says about their attitudes should be uncontaminated by many of the biases that obscure paper-and-pencil measures. 4 experiments are described in which variations of this "bogus pipeline" paradigm were employed. In each case it proved quite possible to validate the device in the s's eyes and to extract theoretically meaningful estimation measures of interpersonal attraction. It is not clear whether the differences between such estimation measures and the standard verbal measures of attitude are based simply on a lie detection principle, on a principle of error preference, or on the fact that the affective component of a complex attitude has been made salient. For whatever reason or reasons, ss attached to the bogus device appear much more ready to express negative affect in experimental settings where one might normally expect the inhibition of such feelings, E.g., toward negroes and the physically handicapped. (44 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: affect & attitude measurement, bogus pipeline paradigm & S's view of validity
Correspondence Address: Jones, E.E.

Title: Measures of response agreement for qualitative data: Some generalizations and alternatives
Authors with affiliations: Light, R.J., Howard U
Abstract: Notes that various procedures are available for measuring agreement among 2 or more os who classify responses among nominal categories, but that different problem situations require different measures. The general model of a contingency table with fixed margins is used to suggest (a) a measure of level of agreement among several os when compared internally, (b) a conditional measurement of agreement for several os compared internally, (c) a test for the joint agreement of several os when compared with a standard, and (d) a statistic for evaluating the pattern of agreement between 2 os. Illustrations are presented for each situation, and results of a monte carlo study of the behavior of the pattern agreement statistic are discussed. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: response agreement measurement among 2 or more Os
Correspondence Address: Light, R.J.

Title: Review and theoretical analysis of the effects of group processes upon individual and group decisions involving risk
Authors with affiliations: Vinokur, A., U. Michigan
Abstract: Presents a theoretical organization of studies comparing individual and group decisions involving risk, emphasizing what has been called the "risky-shift phenomenon." proposed explanations are categorized according to 4 underlying processes: affective, cognitive, interactive, and statistical. A review of these explanations suggests that only 3 specific explanations of the shift phenomenon are viable: 2 complementary cognitive hypotheses (value information relevant to the task; and rationality subjective expected utility) and 1 interactive hypothesis (extremity and influence). An interpretation, consistent with all 3 hypotheses and akin to the partially shared information model of group productivity and the group problem-solving model, is offered. The theoretical significance of studies concerning individual and group risk taking is discussed. The use of behavioral decision theory in particular, the subjective expected utility model for complex, choice-dilemma situations is advocated as the most promising approach for further research in this area. (60 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: individual & group decisions involving risk, affective vs. cognitive vs. interactive vs. statistical processes
Correspondence Address: Vinokur, A.

Title: Group induced shift toward risk: A critical appraisal
Authors with affiliations: Clark, R.D., Florida State U
Abstract: Reviews the empirical evidence on the familiarization, the leadership, the diffusion-of-responsibility, and the risk-as-value hypotheses of the risky-shift phenomenon. Evidence suggests that the occurrence of the phenomenon is dependent upon (a) risk-relevant content, (b) persons who perceive themselves to be relatively risky, (c) heterogeneity of initial opinions, (d) situations for which the consequences of failure are not severe, and (e) risk-oriented instructions. The risk-as-value hypothesis accounts for most of these necessary conditions. However, just how the cultural value of risk is mediated and the relationship between risk and instructions is less clear. (64 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: risky-shift phenomenon, familiarization vs. leadership vs. diffusion-of-responsibility vs. risk-as-value hypotheses
Correspondence Address: Clark, R.D.

Title: Personality and organization theory: A review of some conceptual literature
Authors with affiliations: Lichtman, C.M., Wayne State U; Hunt, R.G.
Abstract: Reviews and comments on the ways different theories have dealt with, or contributed to, the "structuralistic" vs. "personalistic" dilemma. The several views are classed under 4 conceptual rubrics: (a) traditional structural approaches (e.g., marx and weber), (b) modern structural approaches (e.g., argyris and mcgregor), (c) personalistic views (e.g., perceptual theories), and (d) integrating approaches (e.g., system and role models). It is concluded that the extreme variability found within and among organizations renders the 1-sided normative theories less useful in understanding organizational behavior than models that recognize situational contingencies. (3 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: personality & organization theory, structuralistic vs. personalistic dilemma

Title: Problems with the use of "moderator" variables
Authors with affiliations: Zedeck, S., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Defines and categorizes alternative concepts of "moderator" variables categorized in terms of whether they lead to differential validity or predictability, or involve moderated regression techniques. The dissimilarity of results provided by the 3 approaches is discussed in terms of the type of variable (qualitative vs. Quantitative) examined as a moderator and in terms of statistical and methodological problems. The major problems of the operation and identification of moderator variables also are discussed. Utility of the moderator variable concept is examined. (58 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: moderator variable concept, differential validity vs. predictability vs. moderated regression techniques
Correspondence Address: Zedeck, S.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: A coefficient of directional correlation for time-series analyses
Authors with affiliations: Strahan, R.F., U. Rochester
Abstract: Terms the tendency for 2 variables to change values in the same direction from 1 sampling occasion to the next as directional correlation. The coefficient of directional correlation (d coefficient) will often parallel other measures of bivariate association, especially rank correlation. In time-series (p-type) situations, however, directional correlation may diverge greatly. Although modifications of traditional correlational statistics will suffice in some of these situations to reflect the directional correlation present, they will not be generally adequate; moreover, the modifications involve considerable effort. The easily computed d coefficient is recommended when directional correlation is a phenomenon of interest. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: time-series analysis, directional correlation
Correspondence Address: Strahan, R.F.

Title: Intercultural communication and the adjustment of the Sojourner
Authors with affiliations: Brein, M., U. Hawaii; David, K.H.
Abstract: Considers the general description of intercultural adjustment by means of a w-curve function of culture shock. Very little apparent integration exists among the various approaches for explaining or understanding the sojourner's adjustment. Social patterns of behavior and personality traits have not been very successful in explaining intercultural adjustment, while social interaction and background and situational factors have been of somewhat greater value. These divergent approaches can be more meaningfully understood in relation to adjustment to the degree that they facilitate or impede intercultural communication. Thus, intercultural communication appears to be both an integrating and crucial factor for understanding the adjustment of the sojourner. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: adjustment, intercultural communication & social interaction, Sojourner
Correspondence Address: Brein, M.

Title: From probability learning to sequential processing: A critical review
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.R., Ohio State U
Abstract: Considers the failure of several assumptions of stimulus-sampling models in binary prediction studies. An attempt is made to document the direction of current research. Recent trends are examined in research bearing on sequential variables, memory, instructions, discrimination, and age. A number of studies in these areas suggest, contrary to the no-memory, conditioning assumptions of several statistical models, that ss approach the prediction task in an active, hypothesis-testing manner, often relying on prior events in the sequence. Current thinking that attempts to describe these aspects of behavior, often in a cognitive or information-processing framework, is discussed. (4 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: probability learning & sequential processing, memory & instructions & discrimination & age, critical review of research
Correspondence Address: Jones, M.R.

Title: On further conjectures regarding acquiescence
Authors with affiliations: Block, J., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Evaluates the 2-dimensional interpretation of acquiescence offered by P. Bentler, D. Jackson, and S. Messick (see pa, vol. 47:issue 2). Although agreeing that agreement acquiescence (true-responding) is a relatively minor determiner of responses on inventories such as the mmpi, it is argued that acceptance acquiescence (the putative tendency to ascribe characteristics to oneself, regardless of the direction of item keying) is not likely to be of appreciable import for understanding the nature of responses to structured personality inventories. The relationships adduced by bentler et al. As support for their view are evaluated, alternatively, as unresponsive to the evidential requirements of their position. Some recommendations for clarifying or responding to the possible role of acquiescence are offered. (18 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: acquiescence in personality inventory responses, evaluation of P. Bentler & D. Jackson & S. Messick's 2 dimensional interpretation
Index Keywords: article; human; Minnesota multiphasic personality inventory; personality; personality test; psychometry; Human; MMPI; Personality; Personality Assessment; Personality Inventory; Psychometrics

Title: Confidence-rated recall, dr, and tests of Bernbach's finite-state theory in recall
Authors with affiliations: Banks, W.P., Pomona Coll
Abstract: Discusses the measure dr, a signal detection index of discriminability between correct responses and intrusions in recall. Some questions about its meaning and validity are raised. 1 of possibly many methods for testing H. Bernbach's (see pa, vol. 42:1776) finite-state theory in recall without d* (i.e., dr) is suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: confidence-rated recall, test of H. Bernbach's finite state theory in recall
Correspondence Address: Banks, W.P.; Pomona Coll

Title: Invariance of d* in memory: Response to banks
Authors with affiliations: Bernbach, H.A., Cornell U
Abstract: Presents a refutation of W. Banks (see pa, vol. 44:20012) argument that the invariance of type ii d' (or d*, the "corrected-for-guessing" type ii d') with respect to probability correct in recall is an artifact. The replicability of that invariance, the theoretical implications, and the meaning of a criterion in the recall situation are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory & signal detection theory, invariance of type II d*, refutation of W. Banks' argument
Correspondence Address: Bernbach, H.A.

Title: Belief in the law of small numbers
Affiliations: Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Stanford, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tversky, A., Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Stanford, CA, United States; Kahneman, D.
Abstract: Reports that people have erroneous intuitions about the laws of chance. In particular, they regard a sample randomly drawn from a population as highly representative, I.e., similar to the population in all essential characteristics. The prevalence of the belief and its unfortunate consequences for psychological research are illustrated by the responses of 84 professional psychologists to a questionnaire concerning research decisions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: erroneous intuitions about random sampling, consequences for psychological research
Correspondence Address: Tversky, A.; Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Stanford, CA, United States

Title: Psychophysiological approaches to the investigation of desensitization and related procedures
Authors with affiliations: Mathews, A.M., U. Oxford, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Reviews and evaluates all available studies concerning desensitization which utilize measurement. Autonomic changes, particularly in heart rate and skin resistance, do occur following desensitization, and this treatment seems a relatively effective method of modifying such physiological components of fear. The reported effects of phobic imagery are consistently different from those of neutral imagery and show a characteristic response decrement with repetition, although the role played by relaxation in facilitating this decrement remains unclear. Partial dissociation between physiological and other behavioral changes in treatment appears frequently, and may be attributed to varying rates of change in the different systems. Some theoretical accounts of the mechanisms involved in desensitization are discussed. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: desensitization, psychophysiological measurement

Correspondence Address: Mathews, A.M.; U. Oxford, England, United Kingdom

Title: Test anxiety and direction of attention
Authors with affiliations: Wine, J., U. Waterloo, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Reviews the literature and suggests an attentional interpretation of the adverse effects which test anxiety has on task performance. During task performance the highly test-anxious person divides his attention between self-relevant and task-relevant variables, in contrast to the low-test-anxious person who focuses his attention more fully on the task. This interpretation is supported by literature from diverse areas. Treatment and research implications of this interpretation are briefly discussed. (3 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: test anxiety & direction of attention, treatment & research implications, review of literature

Title: College students as therapeutic agents
Affiliations: 731 North Ruston Ave, Tucson, Ariz, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gruver, G.G., 731 North Ruston Ave, Tucson, Ariz, United States
Abstract: Reviews the mutually beneficial effects of college students working as therapeutic agents with individuals in a variety of mental health settings. Studies based primarily on observation and clinical impressionism suggest that college students may be useful as therapeutic agents, and, at the same time, students involved in a helping relationship exhibit personality changes not unlike those effected by more traditional psychotherapies. There is evidence that many unresolved issues will require further empirical investigation before the widespread use of nonprofessionals in psychotherapeutic settings can be sanctioned. (3 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: Validation and extension of the contingency model of leadership effectiveness: A review of empirical findings
Authors with affiliations: Fiedler, F.E., U. Washington
Abstract: Reviews studies of the contingency model of leadership effectiveness. The model is supported by data from field studies but not fully supported by data from laboratory studies. Field and laboratory studies extending the model support the prediction that the situational favorableness dimension moderates the relationship between leadership style and group or organizational performance. Relations between leadership style and group performance for the coacting task groups were similar to those for interacting groups within the same group classification of the model, while training groups appeared to require a predominantly relationship-oriented leadership style, irrespective of the type of leadership situation. (33 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: leadership effectiveness contingency model, validation & extension
Index Keywords: attitude; group psychology; human; human relation; leadership; medical personnel; mental hospital; mental stress; nursing; occupation; orientation; probability; psychologic test; psychology; religion; review; role playing; theoretical model; Attitude; Group Processes; Hospitals, Psychiatric; Human; Interpersonal Relations; Leadership; Models, Theoretical; Nursing Service, Hospital; Occupations; Orientation; Probability; Psychological Tests; Psychology, Industrial; Psychology, Military; Religion and Psychology; Role; Stress, Psychological; Students, Nursing
Correspondence Address: Fiedler, F.E.

Title: Measures of category clustering in free recall
Authors with affiliations: Frankel, F., Rockefeller U; Cole, M.
Abstract: A major problem in the study of organization in memory has been the failure to agree upon an adequate measure of category clustering. A z-score measure, based on a test of the number of runs of similar items in the recall list, is proposed. Several alternative measures, including some that are widely used in the literature, are reviewed and their inadequacies discussed. The various measures are compared using data obtained from a simulated experiment and a previously published developmental study. It is concluded that (a) the measures differ widely in the magnitude of effects they yield; (b) alternative measures tend to accept the null hypothesis when the z score indicates a significant difference; and (c) certain measures are biased to increase solely as a function of longer recall list lengths. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: free recall, z-score as measure of category clustering
Correspondence Address: Frankel, F.

Title: Linguistic deficiency and thinking: Research with deaf subjects 1964-1969
Authors with affiliations: Furth, H.G., Catholic U. of America
Abstract: Reviews recent studies with deaf ss, grouped into subareas of rule learning, logical symbols, piaget-type, memory, and perception. Comparative results on hearing controls are reported with a view to isolating the potential effects of linguistic deficiency on cognitive performance. Conclusions of a previous review are confirmed in that the thinking processes of deaf children and adolescents are found to be similar to hearing ss. It is noted that with few exceptions persons profoundly deaf from birth are severely deficient in linguistic skills in spite of many years of schooling; verbal processes could therefore not account for the emergence of cognitive skills even where developmental lags were noted. Occasional failures on certain logical tasks could be attributed to an unfavorable environment, E.g., in culturally different groups. Data challenge existing theories that base intellectual development largely upon linguistic learning; but confirm piaget's operative theory. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Correspondence Address: Furth, H.G.; Catholic U. of America

Title: Processes of fear reduction in systematic desensitization: Animal studies
Affiliations: State U. New York, Stony Brook
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, G.T., State U. New York, Stony Brook; Davison, G.C.
Abstract: Critically reviews research with infrahumans on fear reduction with respect to the theoretical and experimental underpinnings of systematic desensitization. Several tentative conclusions are suggested: (a) "reciprocal inhibition" represents an unwarranted neurologization of a highly problematical theoretical system (c. L. Hull); (b) the belief that conditioned fear/avoidance is largely unsusceptible to extinction procedures is inconsistent with the firm findings of experimental extinction; (c) the concept of "counterconditioning" is in need of precise, agreed-upon definition; (d) graded exposure to the cs, while not consistently superior in effectiveness to repeated exposure to the full (training) intensity cs vis-a-vis extinguishing fear/avoidance, may be inferior to graded exposure paired with anxiety-competing responses; (e) prolonged, forced exposure to the cs seems, on the whole, to facilitate extinction rather than to "resensitize" the s; and (f) the use of anxiety-competing responses, E.g., relaxation in the standard desensitization procedure, may be important in maximizing nonreinforced exposure to the aversive stimulus. (71 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: systematic desensitization, processes of fear reduction, animals
Index Keywords: animal; anxiety; article; avoidance behavior; behavior therapy; conditioning; fear; human; leisure; psychological theory; rat; reinforcement; time; Animal; Anxiety; Avoidance Learning; Behavior Therapy; Conditioning (Psychology); Extinction (Psychology); Fear; Human; Psychological Theory; Rats; Reinforcement (Psychology); Relaxation; Time Factors
Correspondence Address: Wilson, G.T.; State U. New York, Stony Brook

Title: Empirical comparison of univariate and multivariate analysis of variance procedures
Authors with affiliations: Hummel, T.J., U. Minnesota; Sligo, J.R.
Abstract: Describes a monte carlo study in which univariate and multivariate analysis of variance procedures are used either singly or in combination to form 3 approaches to the analysis of multivariate normal data. Comparisons among the approaches are made with respect to the error rates/comparison, in relation to experiments error rates, and average number of errors in experiments with at least 1 error which were obtained when data generated under 36 combinations of sample size, number of variables, and proportion of variance in common were analysed. The approach consisting of a multivariate analysis of variance followed by univariate analyses of variance is recommended as being the most useful. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: univariate & multivariate analysis of variance procedures, empirical comparison
Correspondence Address: Hummel, T.J.

Authors: Roenker D.L., Thompson C.P., Brown S.C.
Title: Comparison of measures for the estimation of clustering in free recall
Authors with affiliations: Roenker, D.L., Kansas State U; Thompson, C.P.; Brown, S.C.
Abstract: Examines recently developed measures of clustering in free recall and shows them to vary with characteristics of recall unrelated to relative amounts of clustering. Previous measures were shown to vary with factors, E.g., number of categories recalled, the distribution of the total items recalled across categories, and total number of items recalled. For these reasons, comparisons between and within ss, as well as comparisons between experiments, are difficult. An adjusted ratio of clustering measure, which does not vary with irrelevant characteristics of recall, is proposed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: free recall, measures for estimation of clustering & adjusted ratio
Correspondence Address: Roenker, D.L.

Title: Ethnic stereotypes
Authors with affiliations: Brigham, J.C., Florida State U
Abstract: Outlines present conceptualizations of stereotypes in psychology, and discusses theoretical approaches linking ethnic stereotypes to negative attitudes and discriminatory behavior. Research results concerning the content of ethnic stereotypes, their development and resistance to change, and the reciprocal nature of intergroup stereotypes are reviewed. Several critical issues, E.g., methodological problems and the "kernel of truth" controversy, are also discussed. It is suggested that none of the current definitions of stereotype are completely adequate. It is proposed that much of the ambiguity, both conceptual and empirical, in this area may be reduced if stereotypes are regarded as generalizations that are considered as unjustified by the person who affixes the label. There are several types of criteria under which a generalization may be considered unjustified. (3 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ethnic stereotypes & stereotypers, review of empirical investigations
Correspondence Address: Brigham, J.C.

Title: Evaluation of multimethod factor analysis
Affiliations: U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conger, A.J., U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Abstract: Examined multimethod factor analysis and found substantive and mathematical problems. The validity of the assumptions of uncorrelated methods and orthogonal traits within but not between methods is questioned. Multimethod factor analysis was shown by D. Jackson (see pa, vol. 43:12045) to yield a "very satisfactory delineation of trait factors." it is demonstrated that this finding was due to a built-in bias. Suggestions are made as to when multimethod factor analysis might be appropriate. It is recommended that other methods be used and several alternative techniques are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: multimethod factor analysis, evaluation & contribution to D. Jackson
Correspondence Address: Conger, A.J.; U. North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States

Title: Comments on "Evaluation of multimethod factor analysis"
Authors with affiliations: Jackson, D.N., U. Western Ontario, London, Canada
Abstract: Attempts to demonstrate that A. Conger's (see pa, vol. 47:issue 1) proof regarding bias in multimethod factor analysis rests on an irrelevant model. The bias is impossible to demonstrate on either real or monte carlo data. Other conclusions are based upon conger's failure to distinguish between principal components and factor-analytic models, and upon an implicit redefinition of method variance. Cautions are expressed regarding alternative factor-analytic models for the evaluation of multitrait-multimethod matrices because of (a) non-gramian properties of averoid factor-analytic matrices; (b) the possibility of e bias in parameter-fitting models; and (c) the fact that the identification of trait factors permits generalizations about the convergent and discriminant validity of factor scores, and not necessarily about the validity of raw scores. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: multimethod factor analysis, comment on A. Conger's proof regarding bias
Correspondence Address: Jackson, D.N.; U. Western Ontario, London, Canada

Title: Casual assumptions in various procedures for the least squares analysis of categorical data
Authors with affiliations: Werts, C.E., Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.j; Linn, R.L.
Abstract: Evaluates the 3 different least squares methods discussed by J. Overall and D. Spiegel (see pa, vol. 44:1534). It is shown that the 1st 2 methods discussed should not be used to make inferences about causation because they necessarily involve contradictory assumptions about causality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: causal assumptions in procedures for least squares analysis of categorical data, contribution to J. Overall & D. Spiegel
Correspondence Address: Werts, C.E.

Title: Token reinforcement programs in the classroom: A review
Affiliations: State U. New York, Stony Brook
Authors with affiliations: O'Leary, K.D., State U. New York, Stony Brook; Drabman, R.
Abstract: Examines a number of factors which may critically influence the success of a token program including the teacher, the child, the parent, and the system of reinforcement. Methodological considerations (e.g., type of experimental design, o bias, and replicability) are discussed. Several methodological problems in token reinforcement studies are noted. A number of suggestions are presented for the assessment of the long-term effectiveness of token reinforcement programs. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: token reinforcement programs in classroom, development & effectiveness & methodological problems & generalization research, review
Correspondence Address: O'Leary, K.D.; State U. New York, Stony Brook

Authors: Di Giusto E.L., Cairncross K., King M.G.
Title: Hormonal influences on fear-motivated responses
Authors with affiliations: Di Giusto, E.L., Macquarie U., Sydney, NSW, Australia; Cairncross, K.; King, M.G.
Abstract: Reviews studies on the physiological and behavioral properties of adrenaline, noradrenaline, acth, and the glucocorticoids. Evidence indicates that the action of the substances are complementary: E.g., adrenaline and noradrenaline are secreted early as a response to noxious stimuli and influence early acquisition of fear-motivated responses, while acth and the glucocorticoids are secreted relatively late and influence late acquisition and extinction of such responses. Together these substances form a physiological system which appears to significantly influence all stages of acquisition and extinction of fear-motivated responses. This system may also play a significant part in the formation of stress-induced ulceration under certain conditions. Some explanations for the behavioral effects of these substances are suggested. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: adrenaline & noradrenaline & ACTH & glucocorticoids, fear-motivated response acquisition

Correspondence Address: Di Giusto, E.L.; Macquarie U., Sydney, NSW, Australia

Title: Analysis of the combination of perceptual dimensions
Authors with affiliations: Kaufman, H., U. Connecticut; Levy, R.M.
Abstract: Analyzes processing (identification) of stimuli in sets varying along many perceptual dimensions into components related to the processing of each separate dimension. The components, in multidimensional processing, of response bias, interaction, and correlation are defined and reduced to informational terms. It is shown that the total multidimensional information transmission can be partitioned into components corresponding to these concepts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: identification processes with 1- & 2-dimensional stimuli, multidimensional component interaction & perceptual response bias & correlation

Title: Nonparametric indexes for sensitivity and bias: Computing formulas
Authors with affiliations: Grier, J.B., Northern Illinois U
Abstract: Derives computing formulas for 2 nonparametric indexes of sensitivity and bias that have been suggested for signal detectability studies. A relationship is shown between the sensitivity index and p(i), a statistic whose sampling variability is known. An additional index of bias is proposed, which is free of certain inconveniences, yet yields identical isobias contours. Use of the new indexes is illustrated with several sets of data. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: Similarity effects in short-term memory
Authors with affiliations: Shulman, H.G., Ohio State U
Abstract: Reviews the literature on phonemic and semantic similarity in short-term memory and concludes that semantic encoding is readily demonstrated in short-term memory tasks, but only when the task requires it, or when slow rates of incoming information are used. To account for this feature of the data, it is proposed that the encoding of information into short-term memory is a time-dependent process which must be traded off or time-shared with rehearsal. The encoding of phonemic information is assumed to be faster than semantic encoding, leaving more time for rehearsal which is a useful strategy in a short-term memory task. It is concluded that in short-term memory encoding is primarily phonemic unless task demands require semantic encoding. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: short term memory, phonemic & semantic similarity, review of literature
Correspondence Address: Shulman, H.G.

Title: On Brogden's interpretation of factors
Affiliations: U California, Santa Barbara, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harris, C.W., U California, Santa Barbara, United States
Abstract: Discusses the interpretations of factors proposed by H. E. Brogden (see record 1970-01536-001) which provides weights for application to the (generally unavailable) common parts of the data and not to the data themselves. If the weights are applied to the data themselves, the result is 1 of several possible estimates of common factor scores. These weights are not, in general, proportional to the factor pattern. It is suggested, however, that this proportionality can be achieved if the final oblique solution is developed by means of the C. Harris and H. Kaiser (see record 1965-09008-001) independent cluster algorithm. Such a solution guarantees proportionality of 2 sets of weights: those to estimate the variables from the factors, and those that might be used, following Brogden, to estimate factor scores from the variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: factors, interpretation & weights for common parts of data, contribution to H. Brogden's interpretation
Correspondence Address: Harris, C.W.; U California, Santa Barbara, United States

Title: Further comments on the interpretation of factors
Authors with affiliations: Brogden, H.E., Purdue U
Abstract: Discusses the suggestion of C. Harris (see PA, Vol. 46:Issue 4), concerning a paper by H. E. Brogden, that the matrix of weights on the latent test vectors which reproduce the factors is 1 among many matrices that might be used for factor score estimation and that one must choose among these. After clarification of certain features of the paper (see record 1970-01536-001), a distinction is made between factor score estimation and factor intepretation. It is suggested that weight matrices appropriate for estimation may not be appropriate for interpretation. It is concluded that Harris's comments do not seem to be relevant to the earlier paper on factor interpretation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: factors, interpretation & weights for common parts of data, criticism of C. Harris' comments
Correspondence Address: Brogden, H.E.

Title: Note on choosing between competing interpretations of cross-lagged panel correlations
Authors with affiliations: Sandell, R.G., Institutet for Konsumtionsforskning, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Considers the possibilities of drawing causal inferences from cross-lagged panel correlations. Assuming that the effects of a causal state vanish with time, and assuming 3-wave panel data, certain patterns of cross-lagged correlations are open to causal interpretations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: cross-lagged panel correlations, drawing causal inferences
Correspondence Address: Sandell, R.G.; Institutet for Konsumtionsforskning, Stockholm, Sweden

Title: Latitude of rejection: An artifact of own position
Affiliations: Stanford Research Inst., Menlo Park, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Markley, O.W., Stanford Research Inst., Menlo Park, CA, United States
Abstract: Proposes that the latitude of rejection of attitude statements as measured by the method of ordered alternatives is artifactually contaminated by the extremity of own position. An unsuccessful attempt to find a more direct measure of the threshold of rejection is described. It is concluded that differential "ego" or attitudinal involvement across varying own positions cannot be validly inferred by use of either the latitude or the threshold of rejection since the latter ideally requires the property of equal intervals, which is not achieved in most applications. It is recommended that the use of the latitude measures for comparison of differential involvement between respondents be limited to responses of equal extremity of own position. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: latitude of rejection of attitude statements as measured by method of ordered alternatives
Correspondence Address: Markley, O.W.; Stanford Research Inst., Menlo Park, CA, United States

Title: Behavioral contrast: Reinforcement frequency or response suppression?
Authors with affiliations: Freeman, B.J., Southern Illinois U
Abstract: Reviews recent studies dealing with behavioral contrast effects and notes 2 major interpretations of the phenomena: (a) the emotional consequences of response suppression, and (b) changes in reinforcement frequency. Special emphasis is placed on studies which have attempted to separate the effects of these 2 variables. The methodological problems inherent in any attempt to separate reinforcement frequency and response rate are discussed. (48 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: behavioral contrast, reinforcement frequency vs. response suppression
Correspondence Address: Freeman, B.J.

Title: Comment on Overall and Spiegel's "Least squares analysis of experimental data"
Affiliations: Inst. of Behavioral Research, Texas Christian U., United States
Authors with affiliations: Joe, G.W., Inst. of Behavioral Research, Texas Christian U., United States
Abstract: Discusses the model employed by J. Overall and D. Spiegel (see record 1970-01534-001) in their design matrix in the use of a multiple regression technique to the problem of analysis of variance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis of variance, design matrix in use of multiple regression technique, discussion of J. Overall & D. Spiegel's model
Correspondence Address: Joe, G.W.; Inst. of Behavioral Research, Texas Christian U., United States

Title: Physiological measures of sexual arousal in the human
Authors with affiliations: Zuckerman, M., U. Delaware
Abstract: Reviews the physiological methods and findings of research on sexual arousal. The role of and changes in the CNS, autonomic nervous system, hormones, electrodermal potentials, cardiovascular system, respiration, penile erection, scrotum and testes, vaginal blood flow, uterine contractions, temperature, pupillary response, evoked cortical response, and biochemical determinations are discussed. Methodological difficulties in the selection of stimuli and in the assessment of subjective arousal, stimulus-response specificity, habituation, shifting base lines, and the general effect of the experimental situation on results are considered. (79 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sexual arousal, physiological measures, review

Title: Review of the measurement of semantic satiation
Affiliations: State University Coll. New York, Cortland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Esposito, N.J., State University Coll. New York, Cortland, United States; Pelton, L.H.
Abstract: Reviews studies which have used various measures of meaningfulness to measure semantic satiation, and in other ways have attempted to test the effects of semantic satiation. It is concluded that the effects of the phenomenon labeled as semantic satiation have not been reliably measured and are in doubt. An attempt is made to link semantic satiation to what has been called the verbal transformation effect. An alternative approach to the study of semantic satiation is suggested. (75 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: semantic satiation measures, review
Correspondence Address: Esposito, N.J.; State University Coll. New York, Cortland, United States

Title: Last squares methods for locating function shifts and disturbance regions
Authors with affiliations: Bogartz, R.S., U. Illinois
Abstract: Presents some generalizations of a least squares method previously introduced by R. S. Bogartz (see record 1969-06103-001) to fit 2 intercepting lines to a set of data points. Polynomials of arbitrary order are considered instead of straight lines. The concept of a disturbance region is introduced. Methods are given for locating the disturbance region described by 1 polynomial in a portion of the range of the independent variable while another polynomial relates the dependent variable to the independent variable in the rest of the range of the independent variable. A decision rule for deciding the order of the polynomials under consideration, based on a sequence of F tests, is given. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: least squares method to fit 2 intercepting lines to set of data points
Correspondence Address: Bogartz, R.S.

Title: Basic issues in reversal-shift behavior: A reply to Kendler and Kendler
Authors with affiliations: Goulet, L.R., U. Illinois
Abstract: Discusses selected nonmediational factors which affect performance on reversal-shift tasks. The factors highlighted are those associated with the logical operation of reversing and the role of implicit associative responses in discrimination-shift tasks involving conceptually related materials. It is concluded that the reversal-shift vs. 1/2-reversal-shift is not appropriate for use in assessing the unitary effects of mediation or in a test of a mediational model of development. The joint operation of mediational and nonmediational factors in the execution of the reversal shift are also discussed. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: reversal-shift behavior, nonmediational factors, criticism of H. Kendler & T. Kendler
Correspondence Address: Goulet, L.R.

Title: Definitely, our last word]
Affiliations: U. California, Santa Barbara, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kendler, H.H., U. California, Santa Barbara, United States; Kendler, T.S.
Abstract: Argues that the suggestion of L. R. Goulet (see PA, Vol. 46:Issue 3) that 2 rule-based nonmediational mechanisms (doing-the-opposite and frequency cues) can account for developmental changes obtained in reversal vs. 1/2-reversal discrimination-shift experiments suffers from several limitations: (a) means of differentiation of mediated and nonmediated mechanisms is not specified; (b) the doing-the-opposite hypothesis fails to account for several reversal-shift phenomena; (c) the data offered in support of the doing-the-opposite hypothesis possess methodological, informational, and logical insufficiencies; and (d) the frequency theory of verbal discrimination as it applies to ontogenetic changes in reversal-shift behavior is not sufficiently developed to be evaluated. It is concluded that although other formulations may prove to be more valid, at present the coordinated single-unit and mediational stimulus-response formulation most adequately integrates the phenomena associated with developmental changes in reversal-shift behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: reversal-shift behavior, nonmediational factors, reply to L. Goulet
Correspondence Address: Kendler, H.H.; U. California, Santa Barbara, United States

Title: On calculating unbiased information measures
Authors with affiliations: Macrae, A.W., U. Birmingham, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Tested 6 ways of estimating information free from sampling bias, using Monte Carlo methods with a digital computer. 2 techniques had little to commend them, but (a) 2 published techniques were effective with appropriate distributions; (b) calculating bias by the A. G. Carlton (see record 1969-07521-001) formula, with the sample taken as a model of the population probabilities, gave a good correction if the sample was large enough; and (c) estimating the population mean and standard deviation from the sample and using these to calculate population probabilities was effective even with small samples and with a wide variety of distributions, although it was slightly more restrictive in its assumptions than was technique b. A table is provided for hand calculation of technique b. A source for computer procedures for techniques b and c is reported. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimating information free from sampling bias
Correspondence Address: Macrae, A.W.; U. Birmingham, England, United Kingdom

Title: Methodological considerations relevant to discrimination in employment testing
Affiliations: U. Chicago, Graduate School of Business
Authors with affiliations: Einhorn, H.J., U. Chicago, Graduate School of Business; Bass, A.R.
Abstract: Test discrimination can be defined as an over- or underprediction of criterion scores for different subgroups of job applicants. It is shown in the present study that differences between subgroups with respect to test-criterion correlations, criterion means and variances, and differences in standard errors of estimate must be taken into account to avoid unfair discrimination. Utility assumptions, which play an important part in any selection strategy, are considered with respect to test discrimination. A method is developed which utilizes all the relevant information concerning differences between groups to arrive at a nondiscriminatory procedure for selection. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: employment testing, nondiscriminatory selection procedure
Index Keywords: article; employment; female; human; intelligence test; male; negro; perception; psychologic test; social psychology; vocational guidance; Blacks; Employment; Female; Human; Intelligence Tests; Male; Prejudice; Psychological Tests; Social Perception; Vocational Guidance

Title: Talk, silence and anxiety
Affiliations: Veterans Administration, Syracuse, N.Y, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murray, D.C., Veterans Administration, Syracuse, N.Y, United States
Abstract: Reviews articles relating anxiety and verbal productivity. Studies are grouped into those in which anxiety is manipulated by varying environmental stress (situational anxiety), measured by choosing Ss differing in vulnerability to stress (dispositional anxiety), or by ongoing variations in speech disturbances or physiological indexes (concurrent anxiety). There is a strong tendency for verbal quantity to be positively related to dispositional and concurrent anxiety, but negatively related to situational anxiety. Silence tends to be related negatively to dispositional, but positively to situational and concurrent anxiety. These results, plus studies showing verbal quantity 1st rising and then falling as stress increases, appear to indicate a U-curve relationship between anxiety and verbal productivity. (61 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: anxiety & verbal productivity

Title: Retrograde amnesia and conditioned emotional response incubation reexamined
Affiliations: U. California, School of Biological Sciences, Irvine
Authors with affiliations: Dawson, R.G., U. California, School of Biological Sciences, Irvine
Abstract: Examines the CER incubation hypothesis advanced by A. A. Spevak and M. D. Suboski (see record 1969-12407-001). Spevack and Suboski reviewed the evidence bearing upon the nature of the retroactive effects of ECS upon learned responses, and proposed an interpretation for the wide variety of retrograde amnesia gradients reported in the literature. They suggested that the "true" retrograde amnesia gradient occupies only several seconds following learning, and that longer retrograde amnesia gradients reflect, not an ECS effect upon memory, but the halting by ECS of the incubation, i.e., change-over time of an experimentally produced CER. The evidence for this interpretation is considered weak. An explanation of the wide variety of retrograde amnesia gradients, in terms of treatment effectiveness, is put forward as a more reasonable alternative. (40 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ECS, retrograde amnesia gradients & CER, rat, contribution to A. Spevak & M. Suboski

Title: Comparison of normalization theory and neural enhancement explanation of negative aftereffects
Authors with affiliations: Over, R., U. Queensland, Brisbane, Australia
Abstract: Proposes that neural inhibitory interaction underlies negative aftereffects as well as figural aftereffects, with the former occurring when nontopographic principles are used by the nervous system to signal stimulus values and the latter when topographic coding is involved. Relationships between aftereffect data and information available about feature analysis from electrophysiological measurement and contour masking studies are examined with emphasis on tilt and movement aftereffects. It is concluded that even though the neural enhancement position cannot be tested in detail until more is known about tuning characteristics in sensory systems and the way cells respond to abrupt changes in stimulus value, in its present form it offers a more satisfactory explanation of negative aftereffects than normalization theory. There is little to support the latter claim that negative aftereffects occur as by-products of a perceptual adaptation process. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: negative aftereffects, neural inhibitory interactions
Index Keywords: adaptive behavior; afterimage; article; human; illusion; kinesthesia; movement perception; rotation; vision; Adaptation, Psychological; Afterimage; Figural Aftereffect; Human; Illusions; Kinesthesis; Motion Perception; Rotation; Visual Perception

Title: "Equivalence of information in concept identification": Errata
Affiliations: National Inst. of Health, Gerontology Research Center Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arenberg, D., National Inst. of Health, Gerontology Research Center Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: Reports an error in the original article by David Arenberg (Psychological Bulletin. Vol. 74(5) Nov 1970, 355-361). The tenth entry in the fifth column of Table 1 on page 358 should read "A1B1"; and the eighteenth entry in the fourth column of Table 2 on page 359 should read "A2D1.". (The following abstract of this article originally appeared in record 1971-03494-001.) Describes a method which provides equivalent amounts of information for logically equivalent selections in concept identification when Ss select instances. Equivalence is maintained between comparable conjunctive and disjunctive problems as well as within a particular problem type. This equivalence-of-information method permits amount of information gained to be used to measure performance for each selection. The nonequivalence of available information which usually results when solutions are fixed and when Ss select instances is avoided by this method. Data from an experiment in which the equivalence-of-information method is used suggest that amount of initial information gain is a variable that merits investigation and indicate that pooling results of concept problems with high and low initial information may obscure important differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: concept identification, equivalence of information method
Correspondence Address: Arenberg, D.; National Inst. of Health, , MD, United States

Title: Preference strength, expected value difference and expected regret ratio
Affiliations: 1516 Sonoma Ave, Albany, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, W., 1516 Sonoma Ave, Albany, CA, United States
Abstract: Reports that in previous research, strength of preference for 1 gamble of a pair has been related to expected value difference (D) or to an index based on regret (R). In previous studies, however, D and R values have been strongly confounded, and the relations reported could have been due to D, to R, or to both. The mathematical relationships between D and R are discussed, and constructing sets of gamble pairs orthogonal in D and R is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: preference strength for 1 gamble of pair, expected value difference & regret ratio
Correspondence Address: Lee, W.1516 Sonoma Ave, Albany, CA, United States

Title: Where is the person in personality research?
Affiliations: National Inst. of Mental Health, Chevy Chase, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carlson, R., National Inst. of Mental Health, Chevy Chase, Md, United States
Abstract: Examined constraints upon inquiry in personality imposed by current research methods by (a) a survey of empirical work published in 2 major personality journals, and (b) a consideration of methodological and ethical issues raised in recent research criticism. Review of samples, research procedures, and social-psychological context in 226 empirical studies revealed that current methodological practices are incapable of approaching questions of real importance in personality and involve serious problems beyond those noted in recent research criticism. College students were used as Ss in 71% of the studies. Males and females were represented in a 2:1 ratio; 78% were experimental; 78% were limited to a single session; and 57% used deception to manipulate variables. A conceptual schema for ordering personality research strategies, a distinction between contractual and collaborative models of S-E relationships, and suggestions for increasing the relevance and responsibility of personality research are proposed. (65 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: personality research assessment, constraints imposed by research methods & ethical issues & alternative methods
Index Keywords: article; ethics; human; human relation; personality; personality test; research; social psychology; Ethics; Human; Interpersonal Relations; Personality; Personality Assessment; Research; Social Values

Title: Factors influencing the outcome of psychotherapy: A review of quantitative research
Authors with affiliations: Luborsky, L., U. Pennsylvania; et al
Abstract: Reviewed 166 studies of predictions of outcome of individual psychotherapy with adult patients. Predictors are classed as patient, therapist, or treatment factors; the number of predictors which were significant vs. nonsignificant are tallied. By far, the largest number deals with patient factors relatively few with therapist or treatment. Those patient factors which were most often significantly associated with improvement are (a) psychological health or adequacy of personality functioning, (b) absence of schizoid trends, (c) motivation, (d) intelligence, (e) anxiety, (f) educational and social assets, and (g) experiencing (rated from early sessions). Therapist factors are (a) experience, (b) attitude and interest patterns, (c) empathy, and (d) similarity of patient and therapist. Treatment factors revealed 1 main trend: the number of sessions. Methodologies are evaluated, and it is suggested that the main predictors be cross-validated. (7 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: psychotherapy outcome prediction, patient & therapist & treatment factors, review of quantitative research

Correspondence Address: Luborsky, L.

Title: Note on why genetic correlations are not squared
Authors with affiliations: Jensen, A.R., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Reports that correlations between related persons (e.g., twins, siblings, parent-child, etc.) should not be squared in order to determine the proportion of variance they have in common. The correlation coefficient itself is this proportion. The purpose of the correlation is not to predict the variance in a given trait for 1 set of persons from a knowledge of the trait values of their relatives, but to express the degree of overlap in trait variance, i.e., the proportion of variance in common. The rationale of genetic correlations is explained, with examples in terms of a common elements model of correlation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: genetic correlations, reasons for not squaring to determine proportion of variance in common
Correspondence Address: Jensen, A.R.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Authors: Harris D.R., Bisbee C.T., Evans S.H.
Title: Further comments: Misuse of analysis of covariance
Authors with affiliations: Harris, D.R.; Bisbee, C.T.; Evans, S.H.
Abstract: Attempts to clarify some points of disagreement between D. A. Sprott (see record 1970-09565-001) and S. H. Evans and E. J. Anastasio (see record 1968-09688-001). Examination of Sprott's discussion reveals that much of his argument rests on assuming an unconventional random effects model for the analysis of covariance. Sprott used only 1 regression term in his covariance model, which is tantamount to assuming homogeneity of within-between regression and inconsistent with the presence of a separate regression effect associated with treatments. It is reasserted after consideration of Sprott's comments that valid use of the analysis of covariance requires that the covariate be unaffected by the treatment. Consideration of a regression approach when the assumptions of the analysis of covariance are violated is recommended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis of covariance, comments on disagreement between D. Sprott's discussion & S. Evans & E. Anastasio
Correspondence Address: Harris, D.R., Texas Christian U, United States

Title: "Infantile stimulation" in rodents: A consideration of possible mechanisms
Affiliations: King's Coll., Aberdeen, Scotland, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Russell, P.A., King's Coll., Aberdeen, Scotland, United Kingdom
Abstract: Reviews 4 major types of hypothesis concerned with the mediation of the effects of handling or otherwise treating infant rodents and some evidence bearing on them. Existing experiments do not allow a clear statement of the possible roles of (a) tactile stimulation (direct action), (b) hypothermia, (c) maternal behavior, and (d) stress. These hypotheses may not be mutually incompatible, and some possible lines of synthesis are suggested. Conceptual problems attaching to them are emphasized regarding the choice between a relatively nonspecific theory ("total stimulus input," "stress") or 2 or more separate mechanisms (hypothermia, tactile stimulation). It is suggested that the solution may come from a clearer understanding of the physiological systems affected by treatment. (43 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: mediation of effects of early handling & other stimulation, roles of tactile stimulation & hypothermia & maternal behavior & stress, rodent
Correspondence Address: Russell, P.A.; King's Coll., Aberdeen, Scotland, United Kingdom

Title: Inverse relation between the risks of Type I and Type II errors and suggestions for the unequal n case in multiple comparisons
Authors with affiliations: Games, P.A., Pennsylvania State U
Abstract: Criticizes L. Petrinovitch and C. D. Hardyck's (see record 1969-07531-001) recommendations. It is shown that for 2 mean contrasts, the techniques they studied are applications of the same statistic; only different critical values for significance and/or the use of sequential procedures distinguish the tests. Their results mainly reflect the usual relationship that a conservative criterion that protects against a Type I error has a larger risk of Type II error than a less conservative criterion. Petrinovitch and Hardyck's recommendation of the usage of only the Scheffe test and Tukey Wholly Significant Difference test is only an arbitrary preference for conservative tests. Their conclusions on the effects of unequal variances and unequal ns are disputed; an alternative technique for the unequal n case is proposed. (21 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: inverse relation between Type I & Type II error risks & suggestions for unequal n case in multiple comparisons, criticism of L. Petrinovitch & C. Hardyck
Correspondence Address: Games, P.A.

Title: Cue effectiveness and abstraction in paired-associate learning
Affiliations: State U. New York, Binghamton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richardson, J., State U. New York, Binghamton, United States
Abstract: Based on the assumption that stimulus selection in paired-associate learning is the result of an active organized process, a methodological analysis and review of the studies of stimulus selection are presented. Some suggestions are made for further studies of stimulus selection. (64 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: stimulus selection in paired associate learning, cue effectiveness & abstraction
Correspondence Address: Richardson, J.; State U. New York, Binghamton, United States

Title: Heritability as a criterion in the construction of psychological tests
Authors with affiliations: Jones, M.B., Pennsylvania State U., Hershey
Abstract: Many psychologists now and in the past have argued for the heritability of intelligence and many other test variations. However, no psychological test has been constructed using heritability as a criterion and twins as Ss. A twin method for maximizing heritability in the construction of a psychological test is described and illustrated. The heritability criterion in relation to other criteria, and the range of test situations in which the twin method may be used appropriately are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: heritability criterion in psychological test construction, monozygotic & dizygotic twins
Correspondence Address: Jones, M.B.; Pennsylvania State U., Hershey

Title: Quantitative versus qualitative RNA and protein changes in the brain during behavior
Authors with affiliations: Gaito, J., York U., Toronto, Ont., Canada; Bonnet, K.
Abstract: Reviews research purporting to demonstrate the occurrence of quantitative or qualitative changes in RNA and/or protein during simple and complex behavior. Limitations in interpretation of research results and methodological problems are discussed. Much research indicates that quantitative changes do occur. Generally, increments tend to result with mild or moderate stimulation; decrements, with drastic or prolonged stimulation. However, there is no conclusive evidence to indicate that qualitatively different RNA and/or protein species are synthesized during behavior. The necessity for research involving methods sensitive to the detection of qualitative changes is suggested. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: RNA & protein quantitative vs. qualitative changes in brain during behavior
Index Keywords: RNA; animal; article; avoidance behavior; behavior; brain; drug effect; electric shock; hybridization; learning; motor activity; mouse; physiology; rat; sensation; Animal; Avoidance Learning; Behavior; Brain; Electroshock; Hybridization, Genetic; Learning; Mice; Motor Activity; Rats; RNA; Sensation

Title: Experimental inductions of the conservation of "first-order" quantitative invariants
Affiliations: U. Windsor., Div. of Developmental Psychology, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Brainerd, C.J., U. Windsor., Div. of Developmental Psychology, Ont., Canada; Allen, T.W.
Abstract: Reviews experiments that have attempted to train Piaget's concrete conservations. Pertinent theoretical and methodological issues are summarized. Empirical questions are posed concerning: (a) whether or not conservations are trainable, (b) what training methods are most effective, (c) whether or not specific transfer of training occurs, (d) whether or not nonspecific transfer or training occurs, (e) whether or not some conservations are more resistant to extinction than others, and (f) whether or not "natural" conservers are more resistant to extinction than trained conservers. On the basis of currently available data, reasonably complete answers to questions a, b, c, and e are advanced, and judgment is reserved on questions d and f. (58 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: Reply to Wilcock on gene action and behavior
Authors with affiliations: Thiessen, D.D., U. Texas
Abstract: Replies to J. Wilcock's (see record 1969-12595-001) review of single-gene studies of behavior in which he evaluates most studies as "trivial" in that they concentrate on obvious peripheral mechanisms without deep psychological meaning. It is argued that the evaluation neglects that: (a) peripheral mechanisms often account for much of the normal range of variation, (b) single genes can be used to preset physiological parameters, and (c) simple explanations can prevent premature neurologizing. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).

Title: Gene action and behavior: A clarification
Authors with affiliations: Wilcock, J., U. Birmingham, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Replies to D. D. Thiessen's (see PA, Vol. 45:Issue 5) criticism of J. Wilcock's (see record 1969-12595-001) review of single-gene studies of behavior, in which a number of methodological points are raised. It is argued that the previous paper was intended not as a contribution to methodology, but as a critique of empirical findings and their implicit or explicit interpretations. Title: Effects of memory time on successive judgments
Affiliations: California State Coll., los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tate, J.D., California State Coll., los Angeles, United States; Springer, R.M.
Abstract: Considers that the apparent changing of stimulus values during intervals between successive comparisons is both a practical problem in real life and a problem for research employing psychophysical procedures. The literature of 2 distinct sources is reviewed: color memory and time error studies. Contradictory results are found both between and within these sources, though there has been a tendency for the former to find predominantly positive time error and the latter, negative time error. The importance of contextual effects is noted. Discrepant results are also attributed to such factors as differences in stimuli and psychophysical methods employed, methods of data analysis, peripheral aftereffects, adaptation, and practice. A critique is offered and the results of a "model" study are cited that indicate that time errors are seriously affected by the inclusion of poor discriminators and that sex differences in color memory are important. (59 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Authors: Bentler P.M., Jackson D.N., Messick S.
Title: Identification of content and style: A two-dimensional interpretation of acquiescence
Affiliations: U. California, los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bentler, P.M., U. California, los Angeles, United States; Jackson, D.N.; Messick, S.
Abstract: Reviews the methodology involved in identifying and verifying content and stylistic sources of variance in personality inventories. The evidence indicating that response style variance is of negligible importance appears to be far from conclusive. Previous item-reversal studies, which have been considered to yield unambiguous evidence for specific content responding, are shown to be consistent with a style position which differentiates 2 acquiescence processes. Agreement acquiescence, such as true-saying, appears to be a relatively minor determiner of responses to structured inventories. Acceptance acquiescence, such as subscribing to or denying heterogeneous attributes as self-descriptive, appears to be a major response determiner. These 2 types of acquiescence are usually confounded in analyses of personality inventories. Recent studies evaluating the existence of acquiescence variance are summarized. (2 P. Ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: Emergence of a tonic-phasic model for sleep and dreaming: Behavioral and physiological observations
Authors with affiliations: Grosser, G.S., American International Coll; Siegal, A.W.
Abstract: Presents the early evidence for, and later evidence against, theories which consider waking, sleep, and dreaming as discrete states. The newer tonic-phasic model proposed by G. Moruzzi is reviewed. Support for it is drawn from research on the behavior of the CNS, autonomic nervous system, musculature, and mentation as observed during the various stages of sleep. The neurophysiological basis of tonic-phasic events is summarized. The advantages of the tonic-phasic model over a 3-state model are that only the former can accommodate both (a) the heterogeneity of Stage-REM events, and (b) the continuity of certain phenomena throughout all sleep stages. It is concluded that, while the older model was valuable in generating research and methodological innovations, these very developments have made it obsolete. The tonic-phasic model is better suited to the present state of knowledge, and promises to be a valuable guide for further research. (88 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: A-B variable in psychotherapy: A critical review
Authors with affiliations: Razin, A.M., Columbia U., Teachers Coll
Abstract: Reviews research on the A-B classification of therapists under differential clinical outcome, personal characteristics, and analog studies. Outcome work found As more effective with schizophrenics than Bs, whether A-B status was defined by therapy behavior or vocational interests. Later work found Bs more effective with neurotics. Most recent data point to the importance of improvement criteria (As seem more successful in effecting subjective relief, and Bs, in effecting impulse control). Personal characteristic studies find As more trusting, intropunitive, and tolerant of "inner" experiences and spontaneity; more field dependent and personally involved with patients; and more oriented to problem solving than Bs. Largely because of methodological problems, analogs have yielded conflicting data, but they do suggest that, in extended dyadic contact, "complementary" pairings (neurotics with schizoids) are more effective than "similar" pairings (neurotics with neurotics, schizoids with schizoids). It is concluded that As share with and communicate to schizophrenics awareness of idiosyncratic perceptions and that As are able to persuade schizophrenics to trust them. (50 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Title: A-B therapist variable: Real or imagined?
Authors with affiliations: Chartier, G.M., Arizona State U
Abstract: Traces the development of research on A-B therapist "type" as an important variable in psychotherapeutic outcome. 2 sets of clinical studies which suggest that therapist type and patient characteristics interact in producing differential outcome are critically reviewed. Subsequent research, largely of an analog variety, is then evaluated with particular respect to the adequacy with which natural psychotherapy conditions have been approximated. It is argued that the extensive laboratory research has not increased understanding of the original phenomena and that the analog studies constitute a case of premature simplification, since the original clinical research provided an insufficient basis for the interaction hypothesis. (42 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.

Authors: Kavanagh M.J., MacKinney A.C., Wolins L.
Title: Issues in managerial performance: Multitrait-multimethod analyses of ratings
Affiliations: State U. New York, Binghamton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kavanagh, M.J., State U. New York, Binghamton, United States; MacKinney, A.C.; Wolins, L.
Abstract: Examines 3 general issues of dimensionality, validity, and content of ratings of managerial performance in terms of "relevance to the ultimate criterion." It is argued that the multitrait-multimethod design yields the best evidence for investigating these issues. An analysis of variance model with computational formulas for the sums of squares and variance components based on the correlation matrix is proposed for the multitrait-multimethod situation. Using this model, data from 2 studies are examined and compared, relative to convergent and discriminant validity, method bias (halo), and error variance. It appears that this model and the indexes derived from it provide a more simplified and interpretable technique for analyzing and summarizing multitrait-multimethod data. A procedure to improve performance ratings based on partitioning the original matrix is illustrated with an example from the larger data set. (37 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1971 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: dimensionality & validity & content of managerial performance ratings, multitrait-multimethod analyses
